LONDON: Printed for T. and W. LOWNDES, No 77, in Flet-Street.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE Character of LOUISA, in this Play, was evi∣dently written with a Design to offer it to Mrs. SIDDONS; but the Policy of the Theatre not permit∣ting it, the Author has only to observe, that he thinks himself extremely fortunate in having been able to meet with so accomplish'd a Substitute.

The very favourable and flattering Reception this Comedy met with throughout, excepting in one sin∣gle Instance, has induced the Author to retain the Passage which was objected to, in the Copy; that the Reader may be convinced, from tracing the Character, what little Ground there is for supposing he could have been guilty of any intentional Offence, by introducing Party Allusions. The whole Part of Sir GREGORY GLOVETOP, as it now stands, was written above four Months ago; and the Court Phrases were adopted only as incidental to the Character. ☞ The lines with inverted commas are te representation.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
Spoken by Mr. LEWES, in the Character of an "OLD WOMAN."

LG.L: START not, good folks!—I'm only come a wooing—
You know the fair sex ever will be doing—
In Moliere's days the practice was most common
For men to trust their works to some old woman,
Whose matron counsel, and approving choice,
Secur'd their favourite bard the public voice.
Will this bright circle then, who round me sit,
Deny my power of giving weight to wit?
Is there a gallant swain who dares repine,
Struck by the lustre of an eye like mine?
Oh! no—thank Heav'n! the baby-rage is past,
And elder ladies captivate at last:
The full-blown dame, who rules o'er ton and taste,
With rouge for roses, and for lilies paste,
Now reigns the Ovid of a new-made school,
To teach young gentlemen—to play the fool.
If in the tender passion then we shine,
And age can give us "smacks" as well as wine,
No wonder that the fashion is becoming,
And Church, Law, Politics, have their old women.
Our Bard to-night, all anxious for his fate,
Begg'd the indulgence of a tête-à-tête:
First I was coy—but women will give way—
He saw me tender, and produc'd his Play—
Requested I would make his case my own,
And plead a desperate cause before the town.
—Well then,—to speak at once my real mind—
For, on my virtue, I can't be unkind,
Save some old jokes which now and then appear,
And drop in Parliament, as well as here,
I trust this House will take the Treasury side,
Let the debates go on, and not divid.
But as the Scenic Sisters long have varied,
And as we wish our measures may be carried,
To stop the mouths of critic opposition,
We form a tragi-comic coalition:
Water and wine—a beverage half and half—
Broad Humour just peeps in to make you laugh;
While intermix'd the tender scenes appear,
To draw from Beauty's eye Compassion's tear.
Such is our Author's plan—if trite or common,
Condemn me as a doating, false Old Woman!
—But mark, the critic who approves my bard,
May claim a "chaste salute" as his reward.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: SCENE at and near LORD HECTIC'S Country Sea.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
An Avnue leading to LORD HECTIC'S House.

SP.SPEAKER: BELCOUR.
SP.P: COME, come, my dear Loveless, don't be too rigid; you must pardon the extravagances of a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: With all my heart, if they are not carried too far—but I wou'd not have you let your imagination run away with your reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Impossible, my friend—No imagination can do her justice; I tell you, my Harriet is the charmingest girl, the most enchanting creature upon earth: “a per∣son endow'd with every grace, and a mind enrich'd with every virtue.”

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: In that case, my dear Belcour, don't trifle with your happiness—Marry her immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Marry her!—That wou'd be trifling with my happiness indeed—Why, you forget she is the daugh∣ter of our whimsical neighbour here, Sir Gregory
Glovetop, knighted by the old court for a forty yers at∣tendance upon it in the humble quality of gentleman∣usher, and dismiss'd in the late reform, without any fortune but his stiff-topp'd gloves, and remains of a tat∣ter'd wardrobe: think what a charming patrimony I shou'd be heir to—a short sword, and a dress'd coat with a hoop in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Then, my gay, lively friend, let me entreat you, act like a man of honour. Consider the sensibility of an innocent mind; nor sport with the heart you cannot properly make your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Nay, Loveless, now you are too serious. Is there any violent harm in using a little art to give a woman an opportunity of quieting her conscience, and gratifying, without the ceremonies, your inclination as well as her own?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (agitated) Pray excuse me—I am the last man on earth you shou'd consult on such a subject.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Come, come, this gravity does not sit well upon a man whom I have known the foremost in a fro∣lic, and the first adviser of mischief—I expect your assistance in the business.—Say, shall I fairly take her off? or, if you think it better—suppose I pretend to marry her, and so—

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (more agitated) I beg you will urge me no further on this head—Indeed I am very unfit to give an opinion: your conversation probably may affect me more than you imagine—but let us call another topic.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Why, I hope the name of marriage has not frighten'd you, because you have just got rid of the rea∣lity—Every body knows the terms you liv'd upon with Lady Susan; but it was a match of your father's mak∣ing, and, as Heaven has kindly releas'd you from it, why the sooner you forget her the better. So pr'ythee now drop your heroics, and (as you once had a turn for in∣trigue)
put me in a way of obtaining my mistress; for have her I must, cost what it will.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Then, my friend, remember—If you shou'd proceed, and sacrifice to a momentary inclination the rectitude of your heart, you will be as miserable as I am, and live to lament crimes you never can recall.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: My dear Loveless, explain yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Know then, before my marriage with Lady Susan, I was attach'd—tenderly attach'd, to the most lovely of her sex, the daughter of a gentleman who had serv'd his country with bravery and honour—but had retir'd on half pay, to a small neat dwelling near my father's park; where, wholly devoted to the education of his darling child, his only wish was to train her up in the paths of virtue—

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: You affect me exceedingly—pray go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: The vicinity of our abodes gave me frequent opportunities of tracing the sensibility of Julia's mind, “and winning the affections of her virgin heart. Notwith∣standing the humbleness of her fortune, I shou'd un∣doubtedly have married her, had I not too well known the ambitious views and rigid temper of my father.—Transported however with her blooming charms, which were daily heighten'd in my eyes by proofs of growing tenderness, incapable of existing without her;”—and, too conscious of her purity to expect to gain her by other means, I was base enough to listen to the specious arguments of libertine friends, and engaged in a plan to deceive her by a pretended marriage—I see you are shock'd at my villainy.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Pray proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P:
My family at length oblging me to unite myself with Lady Susan, I was compell'd to reveal the fatal secret.—O, Belcour! picture to yourself the distress of an unhappy woman, bereft of that honour, the only
portion which her father's narrow fortune cou'd bestow, by the very man in whom she had plac'd unbounded confidence—(bursts into tears) 'tis impossible to describe the conflict in her bosom. In vain I tried every argu∣ment I cou'd suggest to tranquillize her mind.—She treated my professions of undiminish'd regard with ap∣parent coldness and disdain; and, together with our infant son, left the house where she resided; eluded every re∣search I cou'd make; and at length, I have every reason to believe, fell a victim to my treachery and ingratitude.

DIV3.Q:
“”
Belcour.
I hope not—Come, come, my friend, your apprehensions may be groundless—She may yet live to soothe and cherish your repentant hours—at least your child may want a parent—Why then think of leaving a country where it is your duty to stay?—that if the unfortunate mother is no more, you may call down forgiveness from her relenting spirit, by encreas'd affection to her blameless son.

“”
Loveless.
Alas! that consolation is denied me. He too, poor innocent, hath shar'd his mother's sorrows, and her fate. Notwithstanding my strictest enquiry, I have not been able to gain any tidings of either of them; my only success has been in discovering the re∣treat of Julia's disconsolate father.

“”
Belcour.
But say, how did he sustain so rude a shock?

“
Loveless.
Oh! imagining that she was privy to the imposition of the marriage, he turn'd that rage against his daughter which ought only to have fallen on me, and imprecated severest curses upon himself if ever he saw her again.
”

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: I pity your situation, Loveless: “but re∣collect, that your conduct, tho' criminal, was the result rather of your father's disposition than your own.”

SP.SPEAKER: Lovless.
SP.P:
“No, my friend, I have search'd every ave∣nue
to my heart, and find no hope of consolation.”—I have however written to the injur'd veteran: confess'd the pretences under which his daughter was deceiv'd, and offer'd the only atonement in my power, the entire dispo∣sal of my fortune, as he shall think proper.—I shall wait his answer here; and then bid adieu to a country em∣bitter'd to me by the severest of pangs—the sad remem∣brance of a disgraceful triumph over unsuspecting inno∣cence and tenderest love.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: A truce to these melancholy ideas—“let us, like friends, be useful to each other.” You shall pro∣fit by my advice, and I by your misfortunes.—“I will desist from every dishonourable plan against Harriet; and you shall learn, from my philosophy, to conquer griefs which cannot now avail.” You shall stay with us this summer, and share the rural recreations of this charming seat—Our noble host, my Lord Hectic, will do all in his power to entertain you; and indeed it is im∣possible to restrain the smile at seeing him constantly la∣bouring to become the very character you lament—an anxious wish to be thought a libertine, without constitu∣tion, or even inclination, to be really so.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Absurd man! Yet how happy I shou'd think myself, had my desires never carry'd me further!

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Let me however caution you against▪ his sister, Lady Betty Wormwood, who, without half his good qualities, has a much more mischievous disposition. She does all she can to keep her brother single, expecting to inherit great part of his fortune, and therefore charitably abuses every woman she hears of. My good aunt too, Miss Penelope Zodiac, her guest and companion, tho' she is generally in the clouds, now and then condescends to favour us with some earthly ideas, on purpose to join in the invectives against her own sex, with all that benignity
of disposition for which old maids are so remarkably▪ famous.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: O spare your aunt, at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Not I—I only follow her example—She spares nobody.—But let us adjourn to the mansion; my Lord has by this time, I dare say, finish'd his morning's ride on his chamber-horse; in which case his Irish cousin, Captain Swagger, “who has nothing good about him but his appetite,” will be bawling for his breakfast.—The Captain is very unlike his countrymen; for they are generally brave to an extreme—but he, I believe, is not so.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (in a pensive manner) I am sorry for it—An Irishman without courage is very rarely to be met with; so that the novelty of it will surprize me at least—tho' nothing, I fear, can give me entertainment.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: (taking his arm) Come, come, my friend, dissipate these gloomy thoughts, and endeavour to be, what once you were, the life and ornament of society.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
A dressing-room in LORD HECTIC'S house. He in a robe∣de-chambre. CAPTAIN SWAGGER dress'd in an old uniform, long basket-hilted sword. My Lord seated on a chamber-horse, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: This is the way, Captain Swagger, to get air and exercise at one's leisure, by letters patent, like a gentleman; without being oblig'd to leave one's own chamber, and scour across the country for it, like a post-boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger▪
SP.P: True, my Lord—and, by my shoul, the horse won't be easily knock'd up.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: (getting off) There, there—I have taken a pretty long ride to-day. (coming forward) What a fine thing it is to be hale and hearty! (coughing) one gets thro' so much fatigue without minding it; and looks as fresh as a rose after all (coughing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Fait, and you may say that, my Lord—for I never minded any thing; and, I believe, I look full as much like a rose as yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Fore gad, my valiant Captain, thy ap∣pearance is a little too terrific for the tranquillity of my country-seat—thou must really change that warlike habit of thine, and think of more peaceable services.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O be easy now, my Lord, and let my habits alone. To be sure I've a custom of looking pretty manly in the face, and that's no common habit now amongst gentlemen; and, thanks to St. Patrick, I have a tolerable good constitution;—but so much the better for your Lordship, for I have been making pretty free with it these ten years past—for the sake of your reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Psha! Swagger, it is not thy consti∣tution I complain of, but thy head—thy crazy head, that cannot carry into execution the glorious enterprizes I plan for thee. What is the cabinet without the key? or any of the Boards without the first Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O, boo woo, don't be after comparing me to a board, and praising your own qualifications, when you know they're all mine: you have forgot what use I was to you when we travell'd together; how I constantly remember'd what was to happen, and carried away all the things we left behind us—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Yes, yes, I remember you pocketed the old bills, when I had paid the reck'ning.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Faith and troth but I paid the reck'ning too—for the score was mark'd upon my back.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
Well, but I forget all this while the
interests of my dearest Louisa—a rapturous lover like me (coughing) does not always carry his wits about him—What answer did'st thou bring from her?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O fait, and it was very difficult to remem∣ber, for it was no answer at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: How! what!

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, the old knight here, Sir Gregory Glovetop, could not help thinking my tête-à-tête visits to Madam Louisa, especially as you were al∣ways one of the party, would do his daughter Harriet no good—so he has sent madam a-packing, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Louisa turned out of Sir Gregory's house! what havoc I make amongst the women!—But is she really turn'd adrift on my account?—Harkee, sirrah, don't you know that I am all feeling—a mass of combustible sensibility? ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Well, what if you are—there's no occasion to go off here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Why, art thou ignorant that I consider myself the sole and undivided property of the ladies, and that I build my reputation upon theirs?—Have not I set my heart upon carrying off this fair widow? and do I ever fail in matters of love? (coughing)

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Well, and hav'n't you sacrific'd the poor ereature's happiness, by frightening away her friends from her? and can't you be satisfied with the distress you have already occasioned, and the ill reports that are spread about her?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: No—there are no ill reports that I have been successful—so what distress is there to satisfy me? Fly therefore about the neighbourhood, and find where my treasure is hidden.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O now, if that is all your treasure, be quiet and easy; because why, when one treasure is lost, another may be found—that's my philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Hold thy profane jargon—dost thou think the delicacy of my passions are so easily charm'd? and that I am form'd horribly robust, as thou art, with∣out a grain of sensibility—a heart of stone, and nerves of cast iron?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Nerves of cast iron!—upon my word, and very pretty things too. It may be the fashion to be sick to death, and sensible alive, as they call it, to every thing; but, thanks to St. Patrick, I never was either one or the other; and I hope I never shall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Don't put me in a passion, Captain—but let me not see thy face again till thou hast found her.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: (turns himself away) O, to be sure, I will face about, if you please; and, if I can't find her, when I return why I must come in again in the same manner as I go out. It is only walking backwards, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: (coughing) What a dreadful tax it is upn a man of fashion, to have his peace interrupted by the impertinence of a woman's beauty!—That a pair of black eyes should totally relax the fibres, and a fine shape de∣stroy the whole nervous system!—Well, I have nothing for it but a good constitution to depend upon.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
An Apartment in LORD HECTIC's house.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter LADY BETTY WORMWOOD, and Miss PENELOPE ZODIAC, disputing.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I tell you, Lady Betty, that science, and a knowledge of mathematics, geography, and tactics, is the first stone in the character of an unmarried wo∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: To be sure, Miss Penelope Zodiac, geography and tactics are unquestionably the principal supports of a woman's character; though, owing to the unaccountable ignorance of mankind, three parts of our sex get married without any such perfections.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Get married!—so much the worse. If women's minds were properly filled with elaborate re∣searches, they would have no vacancy for such unseemly ideas. Think of the divine charms of philosophy—pure ethics—to wander from pole to pole, and to swim in the milky way.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Undoubtedly, Madam, if a lady must swim, the milky way is as well as any other; and, to a roving mind, the wandering from pole to pole may be very delightful; but I should imagine the less a woman wanders the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Well, thank Heaven, my mind, I am proud to own, has never descended so low as to con∣template that improper creature a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: For goodness' sake let us then change the discourse, and talk about a woman.—What think you of Louisa, the object of my brother's present pursuit?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: What that affected widow that lives at Sir Gregory Glovetop's, and pretends to be fond of nature; though she knows no more of the planetary system, than I do of making a pudding?—Oh, I detest such audacious creatures, as every lady of sentiment ought to do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: For my part, I believe the wretch has the confidence to think that my brother entertains ho∣nourable designs upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Entirely owing to her ignorance of mathematics: had she been studying Euclid she could not have had such a thought.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P:
Perhaps not—but, lest the lady should
never take to studies of that kind, I will tell you what I have done: you must know, though I am naturally of a tender disposition, and extremely averse to every thing that's cruel—yet, for the sake of example, I have pre∣vailed upon old Sir Gregory to turn her out of his house. My brother will most probably forget her; and the minx will be happily left to starve in some distant country, so that we sha'n't be shock'd with her distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: A very kind precaution—but indeed, Lady Betty Wormwood, your brother is a sad libertine—quite an ignis fatuus, as the learned call it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: He certainly is, and therefore he had much better remain single, and keep his fortune in his own family.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: To be sure, the whole world had better remain single.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: He will be delightfully disappointed when he finds the bird is flown. I have a very great regard for my brother, but I do love to see him mor∣tified.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: So do I, Lady Betty—because he will never allow that we women have superior understandings to the men. Oh, what was Plato, for instance, to the queen of Sheba? or what would the duke of Marlbo∣rough have done with the maid of Orleans?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Done with her!—why whatever he pleas'd—men of prowess are always successful—for instance, myself (coughing).

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I beg, my Lord, you will not shock my hearing with any improper compliments to any body—you will please to recollect I am an unmarried woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Oh, my brother is only going to display his own qualifications; and surely they can't shock any lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: No, to be sure—for egad I adore the whole sex—strive to make them all happy, (coughing) from the duchess down to the milk-maid; and, to do my∣self justice, few people more fortunate (coughing). Wo∣men of science, as you call them, are the easiest things in the world; as, for instance—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: (alarm'd) Bless me! I hope your lord∣ship is not going to be rude.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Rude, Miss Penelope!—in this company (surveying her)—I have not such an idea.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Indeed, my Lord, I blush for your sublunary conduct;—why can't you indulge your genius in a nobler way, and attach yourself to the heavenly bo∣dies, as I do—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Why I do attach myself to the heavenly bodies; only I don't look among the stars for them, as you d.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Upon my word, if your lordship keeps going on in this manner I must quit the premises—I shall be afraid to trust myself under your roof—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Dear Miss Penelope Zodiac, don't have the least apprehension—you are perfectly safe, believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I don't know that, my Lord—when you are carrying on your intrigues directly within our vortex, as one may say. I am told here is a wanton wi∣dow hard by.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Ah! the widow's situation at present is not quite so agreeable. But we seem to be playing at cross purposes; so, ladies, I'll attend your tea-equipage immediately—I have two or three morning petitioners to dispatch, who are waiting without: they won't de∣tain me long; for I always promise every thing they ask, to shorten conversation—and then you shall see what havoc good spirits and sound health (coughing) can make amidst your French rolls and butter. [Exit Lady Betty.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: (going) Au revoir, my Lord.—But I wish you wou'd not turn so much upon your own axis.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Very whimsical advice.—Egad, I be∣lieve the old spinster wants me to take a turn with her.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
An Apartment in an old House belonging to Sir GREGORY GLOVETOP, furnished in a very antique manner, decorated with Ornaments of Heraldry, Coats of Arms, Badges, Ban∣ners, and antient Orders.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter SIR GREGORY, somewhat heated, followed by HARRIET.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Upon my decorum, Harriet, I am quite ashamed of you.—“”You have no idea of punctillo, and form, and etiquette, and ceremony; not an atom of the old court about you, as my name is Sir Gregory Glovetop.

DIV3.Q:
“”
Harriet.
Consider, dear Sir, the difference of our years: saving your presence, it is not to be expected that I should wish to have any thing old about me.

SP.SPEAKER: "Sir Gregory."
SP.P: Why, child, I swear by my knight∣hood, you are as rude and unpolished as a beef-eater.—Will you never entertain a proper respect for antient cus∣toms?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Lord, papa, am I to be blamed, because I have the misfortune not to be so old as my grandmother?—Besides, I have been bred up in the country, and can∣not have had an opportunity of seeing or improving from courts.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P:
What! not had an opportunity of im∣proving! han't you seen me? Study my manners and ad∣dress;
and then learn what would be becoming in a young woman. A fine example, indeed, thrown away, if I, who have lived in the circle, presided at drawing∣rooms, bow'd at levees, eat cake and caudle-royal, should have danc'd, and bow'd, and eat for no purpose!—I beg I may hear no more of this uncourtier-like friend∣ship you profess for Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Sure, sir, our long intimacy, her amiable dis∣position, and her hard fortune, together with the manner in which she was obliged to quit our house, after having been admitted into it as a resident, must leave a regret upon my mind, which I hope you will allow not quite unjustifiable.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Quite the reverse, I assure you; and not a precedent for it in the red book. I allow no friendship, but of form: when people are out of place, the ceremony is to forget them—a squeeze by the hand—or a proper nod of the head—but no more;—no sorrow upon the countenance, except at a court-mourning.—That was the rule in my time, and I never can forget the lord chamberlain.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: But, my dear papa, was it not rather unkind to compel my unhappy friend to retire from beneath your roof, because that odious Lord Hectic would plague her with unsought-for solicitations; and to force her and her little infant to seek a new habitation, for impertinencies which hurt her peace more than they cou'd yours?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Hush, child! Lords have great privi∣leges, and, at the old court, carried a dignity which, with a proper dress, a full-bottom'd periwig, and a short sword, were truly respectable.—But, let me tell you, that no person who has had the honour of dining with the corps diplomatique, can or will brook great coats and dirty boots—I mean no offenc to the peerage.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P:
My dear papa, can you imagine, that a
mind like Louisa's, so worn with anxiety, can thus easily regain its happiness?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Ay, I always thought she was too pen∣sive for a well-bred person. You should have seen me at a birth-night, bowing, and simpering, and squeezing, and nodding, and handing wine among peers and peeresses, laced down to my shoes; stockings rolled up; and periwig in full float; then, I think, you would have taken me for somebody—every feature curl'd into a smile, and not one look of thought upon my countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: But surely, grief was natural to the tender∣ness of a disposition like Louisa's—her fortunes were of the humblest kind, and she had probably lost the husband of her fondest affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: The French Duchess of Pantoufle lost five husbands, and always appear'd in her place.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Then, Sir, consider the unprotected state of her little one—the sweetest boy! you could not help being pleased with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Yes, the boy might have done for a page—I had some thoughts of teaching him the true court-step myself—but that ministry are out, and so we'll think no more about them.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: My dear sir, picture to yourself her situation—alone, deserted—no friend to sooth—no parent to pro∣tect.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Ay, there again;—her father is still liv∣ing; why don't he send an envoy, or plenipo, to the place of her residence?—you say, he was displeased with her marriage; what of that? there is no occasion for affection to preserve ceremony—I remember Count Bal∣derblouski, from Poland, had no intercourse with his child for twenty years; yet they always kept up deco∣rums, solemnized their birth-days at five hundred miles distance—and hated each other with civility.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Wou'd Louisa had a father's home, as I have, to retreat to, instead of being forc'd to seek an asylum among strangers; who, unacquainted with the gentleness of her disposition, may aggravate the sorrows which they cannot feel!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Can I help it, child, if every one is not so well versed in politeness as I am?—Besides, I am natu∣rally gentle, and have said to her a thousand times, that no one would be so charitable to her as myself.—Ma'am, says I to her, in the kindest manner, you are left desti∣tute—a kind of outcast—but what of that? behave properly, and I will condescend to give you a certain degree of consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Then, Sir, recal your cruel decree, and in∣dulge your Harriet with the pleasure of bringing back under the same roof the friend and companion of her earliest years.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: What, child! when I have told you I am gentle, dare you prescribe to me how I ought to act! I that was the corner-stone of the old court; brought up amongst maids of honour and bed-chamber ladies, “admitted to the back-stairs, and have peep'd through the closet key-hole.” O, I am petrified by your pre∣sumption!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: My dear papa, I hope you are not offended at my presuming to plead the cause of friendship—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Yes, child, I am offended.—Now, indeed, people don't know when they ought to be so;—affect to be pleased, when they are quite out of humour; laugh at every thing; and want a demeanor in their resentments: but, thank Heaven, I am better acquainted with dignity.—The old Lord Burleigh, when he was offended—he—hum!—I believe he walked off, and said nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P:
(sola) And must I sacrifice to these unmeaning forms of my father each emotion of my heart? forsake my
virtuous and much-injured friend, in whose sweet society I have enjoyed so many happy hours, and from whose gene∣rous counsels my inexperienced youth has reaped so much advantage?—No; every sentiment of gratitude and hu∣manity forbid it. I have already consulted my Belcour on the occasion: his tenderness for me is, I think, sincere; and he must doubtless prize that warmth of friendship in his Harriet's bosom, which may lead him to expect she can as forcibly feel a softer passion. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
A retir'd Cottage, with a View of the Country: A Seat at the Foot of a Tree, near the Door of the Cottage.
DIV3.STAGE: LOUISA coming forward with a Book.
DIV3.P: HOW vain is the philosophy which books would preach up to us, to assuage the real anguish of the heart!—The wounded mind, that wanders to them for consolation, returns with double force to home-felt grief; and, while it feels poignantly for feign'd distress, with added pangs will contemplate its own.—Then how can I expect to find relief from study? mark'd out for af∣fliction from life's earliest dawn, its ripening day but brings encrease of woe.—Alas! that charming season of youth, when all around, gay, flattering expectation gilds the scene, and every coming hour seems wing'd with new delight, for me teem'd only with misfortune!—Born with a heart too tender, and perhaps too sanguine, I fond∣ly plann'd delusive schemes of happiness, which Fate de∣creed I never should enjoy. One friend,—one only friend the world had left me; she too I now must lose.—Poor Harriet!—“tho' tormented by the caprices of a weak father, may'st thou never suffer half the misery of thy distracted friend!” My child too,—my little smiling boy,—he must be for a time deserted.—Alas! who knows how long?
DIV3.STAGE: Enter ANNA and the child from the cottage.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: My dear lady, every thing is ready, as you order'd, and your writing-box and the miniature picture are left upon your table.—But, my lov'd mistress—forgive my boldness—can you really bear to leave your sweet companion behind you?—will you indeed trust him with me while you are gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Trust him with you, my Anna! Alas▪ to whom else can I bequeath him?—The unfeeling world hath barr'd each door against him, and poverty's hard hand leads forth his infant steps.—Now, too, he must forego a parent's tenderness;—but I hope our separation will not be long; and you, who feel for him a mother's love, will, I think, guard him with a mother's anxiety.

SP.SPEAKER: Child.
SP.P: Pray, mayn't I go too?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: No, my angel,—my journey would fatigue you—its object is but to do you service—may its wishes be accomplished! and may my darling child's maturing years be happier than his morn of life has promised!—Here, Anna, take this trifle (giving a purse) I wish it were larger for your sake—but Fortune allows me to be profuse of nothing but my thankfulness;—it will serve, perhaps, to defray the necessary expences of my Fred'ric; for the rest, dispose of it as you like.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Pray now, my dear lady, excuse me.—Indeed I cannot accept of it.—You have been always a tender mistress, and I have sav'd a something in your service,—a trifle indeed, but how can I employ it better than in returning it to the dear child of her from whose goodness first it came?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P:
Hold, hold; your generosity oppresses, over∣powers me—but some one is coming this way:—retire, therefore, for a moment—I would not that strangers
should know how sensibly I'm affected, by the exalted behaviour of my more than friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: My dearest Louisa, I would not lose an instant in hastening to you, the moment I cou'd escape from my father. But wherefore these tears?—Your boy—my little play-fellow, I hope, is well.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Well, very well;—I grieve only to be the cause of so much trouble to my Harriet.—Alas! I seem born to give uneasiness to all my friends;—at least the few I have left.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Come, my Louisa, conquer this despon∣dency—indeed you have a great many friends—every good mind must be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: How soothing is your sensibility!—why am I flatter'd with kindness, only to make the parting with it more severe?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Parting, Louisa! what is it you mean? Do not imagine this misunderstanding can long continue—assure yourself we shall soon again be happy; and this little interval will but increase the charms of our renewed society.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Impossible—my resolution is taken:—there is a person whose regard, notwithstanding long neglect, I still hold it my duty to solicit:—once he has refused, cruelly refused to hear me—shou'd his unkindness still continue—but no matter.—At a distance, Harriet, I may perhaps have courage to reveal to you a story, which my blushes wou'd prevent me from doing in your presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P:
(Changing her manner) What then, my fair friend,—there is a some one whose regard you are more anxious to solicit than that of your humble servant.
—In truth I ought to have consider'd that immoderate grief in a widow, a young, handsome widow, like you, was not altogether so natural.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed, Harriet, you mistake me much.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: In truth but I do not.—No wonder that the gallant addresses of our neighbour, Colonel Quorum, that military dispenser of warrants, and settler of disputes, should all be lost upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Lost upon me indeed!—O my gay, sprightly, yet feeling friend! wou'd I cou'd always be the occasion of calling forth that charming vivacity! The Colonel, I agree with you, has certainly an excellent heart, and not∣withstanding his violence, and his continued swearing—

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Swearing!—Oh, he is a justice of peace, you know, and is us'd to it;—besides, a lover shou'd always have a good stock of oaths to begin with;—but, laughing apart, Louisa, he has an ample fortune, and is sin∣cerely attached to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: How can you talk to me seriously on such a subject?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Nay, if your affections are really engaged, I mention it no more;—but otherwise I shou'd have said, that your duty to the deceased has been more than paid; and, though I cannot imagine that here your heart wou'd be deeply interested, yet you have a child, whose wel∣fare is your care—independence is offer'd to him: he has no father's fortune, give him therefore a claim to inherit one.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Pray drop the subject,—perhaps he has a fa∣ther, and may not ask the bounties of a stranger;—per∣haps—what am I saying?—Pray Harriet, believe me, I was thinking of something else, and did not properly at∣tend to your discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P:
(taking her hand) And is there, my Louisa, any thing which you dare not reveal to your friend?
Some private grief that you think her unworthy to be trusted with.—Tho' all your Harriet's inmost thoughts have long been lodg'd in her Louisa's bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Madam, I am so glad I have found you: for I've been in every corner of the parish these two days, with a message from my master, Colonel Quorum, and no tidings cou'd be heard of you.—So I went into the ale-house hard by; for there, thinks I—but I beg pardon for being out of breath.—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: There is no occasion to beg pardon,—but pray don't be in such a hurry;—you'll suffocate your∣self, Mr. Pickaxe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: True, madam, I cannot talk so fast as the women, as I say to my wife;—but no matter for that:—so, going into the ale-house, I heard as how a strange lady, which I knew must be you, was come to live here∣abouts, and that Sir Gregory Glovetop,—I beg your papa's pardon, Miss Harriet—had turn'd Madam out of doors, which was being a little upon the rumbusticle with a lady, says I,—but no matter for that;—I never talk of any body's affairs but my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: If you keep to that resolution we shall never hear any thing of your master's.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P:
O Madam, never fear him—he'll make him∣self heard when he's in a passion;—and, indeed, to speak by the statutes, as master calls it, he is in a very great passion for Madam Louisa; for the moment he heard how your ladyship was treated, quite no better than a vagrant, he swore he would commit the whole parish, and Sir Gregory Glovetop into the bargain—but Lord, Sir, says I—its all the better for your worship, for the lady, as I may say, being a little at a nonplus, and not knowing
where to turn herself, who knows but she may face about to your worship's regimentals?

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Why, Mr. Pickaxe, you seem to have form'd a very just opinion of the sex—

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Lord, Ma'am! as I said to my master when he had done swearing, I know them—Madam Louisa must be in trouble: she is not like Miss Harriet, as I said, gallanting it away of her own accord with the gentleman in the green walk, because she is in love with him her∣self—No, no, Madam Louisa wants pressing, and a bit of vexation—and then she'll come to—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sure, my honest friend, you cannot think I want vexation; however, I am not going to be angry, for if such is your interpretation, Mr. Pickaxe, it will be very dangerous to be vex'd in your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Why it's my fault, as I say to myself, to be sincere;—for, as I said to his worship, what can you want with a wife? have not you the disturbances of the whole parish to settle, and to swear (I mean to hear people swear) from morning till night—and then, since you took to train∣ing volunteers, says I, and to firing great guns, and have peace neither at home nor abroad, what the Devil, says I to his worship, can you want with a wife?

DIV3.Q:
“” Harriet.
And what could his worship answer to that?

“ Pickaxe.
Ah, madam, its my fault not to be minded, because I say little; but I verily believe as how, if Ma∣dam Louisa wou'd but listen to his addresses, there is not a justice of peace in the whole hundred that wou'd commit matrimony sooner— ”

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Upon my word, Mr. Pickaxe, the Colonel has no occasion to say much for himself, while he has so able an advocate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P:
Ah, madam, a few kind words from you wou'd make a man of him again; for, to say truth, he is
sadly out of sorts—can't sign a warrant in peace.—Do, Madam, sent him a little comfort, be it ever so cold;—do but say you love him now—if its only to please him.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed, my good friend, I cannot say that to any man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Well, Ma'am, if you can't love him, say you'll marry him, and let t'other come by and by;—I'm sure Miss Harriet here wou'd not be so difficult.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: I beg, Mr. Pickaxe, you will not be fancying things about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Fancying things!—No, Ma'am, I leave that to the gentleman in the green walk.—I ask pardon for being sincere;—but, as I was saying, if you wou'd only be so good as to give him a kind look or two, just as much as to `say I see you,' he'd go quite out of his wits, and be the happiest man in the world.—Come, Ma'am, I'll tell him you like his carriage—his air, and the calf of his leg.—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I request you will tell him no such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: That you think him a fine officer, and a good justice of peace.—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I make no doubt but he is both; but let me intreat you not to mention that I say any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Well, Ma'am; then I'll only say that I said it—and that you said nothing. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Ha! ha! upon my word there is something entertaining in the absurdities of that fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yes, for they have occasioned a momentary suspension of my sorrows.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, my dear Louisa, explain to me the mystery which, before we were interrupted, your last words conveyed.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Oh Harriet! spare me on that subject.—It is a long and melancholy tale, that will require a resolution which at present I cannot command.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P:
Will you then forsake me? and leave her,
whom you used to call the partner of your heart, a stranger to those disquiets which she would gladly participate, and anxiously endeavour to sooth?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My kind, my tender Harriet, assure yourself, cost me what it will, before we finally separate, you shall be fully acquainted with the sad story of Louisa's woes—then perhaps my soften'd friend will find another and a newer tear to give to my misfortunes—perhaps she'll clasp me nearer to her heart—perhaps she'll hold me at a fearful distance. However it may turn out—believe me, the parting pang will deeply rend my bosom; and absence, time, nor circumstance, shall ever erase the fond remem∣brance of my Harriet's virtues.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
An Apartment in LORD▪ HECTIC'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter LORD HECTIC, LOVELESS, and BELCOUR.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Yes, yes, Belcour, I know you and your friend Loveless must laugh at us country 'squires. You London gentlemen have no taste for rural charms, and the ruddy looks of the country—hem! hem!—for my part, however, give me the old English constitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: I hope your Lordship feels no necessity for that wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Me! hem! by no means—I speak only of the charms of rising early in a morning, taking a long ride, breathing the keen air, hem!—and pursuing those active pleasures that strengthen and invigorate, and make us Englishmen the terrors of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Bravo, my Lord!—to say truth I shou'd not have suspected your having a taste for rural sports, shoot∣ing, fox-hunting, and the et caeteras of a country life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: No more I have—do you think I want to rival my game-keeper?—Those were the barbarou arts of our ancestors in the days of boxing, who affected to be stronger, hem! than a gentleman ought to be—No, no, I mean the little innocent delights—the smiling wreath, hem!—and myrtle bower.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord, and the smiling beauties in that bower—a London out of town—the charms of Pall∣mall in the groves of Hampshire—that, I presume, is your Lordship's rural life; at least if we may trust the gallant chronicles of your Lordship's seat.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: O fie! Belcour—But do they say that I'm no Joseph?—Juvenile follies, though, shou'd be for∣given—Some people do these things out of vanity, that surprizes me; merely to be talk'd of, Mr. Loveless.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: And a miserable vanity it is, as your Lord∣ship observes. Passion, indeed, may plead some excuse for a momentary indulgence of it; but we should ask no triumphs for our infirmities.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: True, Mr. Loveless—upon my word—a very—hem! hem! a very just observation.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Aye; but then, my Lord, that wou'd be too severe a judgment, were it to extend to every little gallan∣try with a grizette.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: True again, my dear Belcour; some al∣lowance ought to be made, for, hem! the errors of the constitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: And upon my word his Lordship has some right to plead weakness in that article—therefore I retract my opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Ah, I fear you do but flatter me, now—for you know, Belcour, I am a little of a—hem! of a li∣bertine; and, to tell you the truth—but your friend Love∣less there looks so moral and serious, it's impossible to say any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Oh, a town man—a perfect town man—don't mind him—a mere hypocrite.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Egad then I need not mind him—All a sham, ha? not so innocent as one wou'd imagine—never deceived any woman. (smiling.)

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Psha! no more than you have.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: I believe, my Lord, we have neither of us had any transaction of that kind to boast of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Boast of!—by no means—but, entre nous, I must confess, without vanity, that I do succeed pretty well amongst the ladies—hem! A peer, you know, carries an appearance—a blaze, a hem! hem!—the girls are astonished—dress makes its way—and—a star for a gar∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: A garter! O that's the game you pursue.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: To be sure—woman is the game of a man of spirit—hem! and I have found out such an ob∣ject to chase; and, with your assistance, have no doubt but we shall run it down.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Can my assistance be necessary? I fear, my Lord, it will not much avail.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Yes, yes, boys, you must all assist; and fine sport we shall have of it—for the lady affects to have virtue, and stuff of that kind!—hem!—but in the country we do as you do in town, treat it as a pretence—mere pre∣tence. Besides, I only begin with coaxing, and if that won't do, I proceed to vigorous measures—hem! hem!—that's the way to succeed with the women—en't it, Bel∣cour?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Your Lordship, indeed, wants little instruc∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
No, no; 'egad I am pretty well at those things—'tis not a little that stops me. You wou'd go thro' any thing, I dare say, for a fine woman, Mr. Love∣less. I mean it as a compliment—so don't be ashamed—
But I won't be cruel to the poor creature. I intend to behave well; and, when my passion is over—hem! and if she has shewn a regard for me, I shall marry her to a good sort of fellow you may have seen in the house—a Captain Swagger.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Faith, my Lord, and here I am, like the old proverb about bad news; and a sad story I've found out, for Madam Louisa's not to be heard of—so I cou'd dis∣cover nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: What then, you have found out a sad story about nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: To be sure—for they say she is going to be married to Colonel Quorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Married! undone—

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Yes, she has undone herself—in order that she mayn't be ruined.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: What reason hast thou to think so?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: First and foremost, as I was taking a little dram at the public-house, just to cool me—who shou'd come by but Mr. Pickaxe, the Colonel's clerk▪ or rather his aid-de-camp, in such a hurry—and, though I asked him to take a sup, he wou'd not open his lips upon the subject—upon my shoul he never refused it before—a bad sign that.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: To be sure; an unusual sobriety looks like marriage—an unlucky omen for your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Secondly, when I pass'd the Colonel's house, I observed the great gun, that used to be in the dog-ken∣nel, was haul'd out before his door, by way of defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Nothing can be more probable—he expects an attack, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P:
Thirdly, upon the grass-plot before the
parlour-window, what shou'd I see, but his old regimental waistcoat and breeches laying out to air.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Zounds, there's certainly a something in the wind.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: And, fourthly, the stag's horns are taken down before the gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Not a trait of the batchelor remaining—Why, your Lordship will lose the honour of providing for the lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Gad zooks! after all the trouble—hem! hem! I have had, and the secrecy I have kept—to be disappointed—hem!—no respect to a man of fashion! hem! Zounds! I will know where she is gone to—that old fool, Sir Gregory Glovetop, shall inform me why he dar'd turn a lady out of his house that I set my heart upon: hem! hem!—pray, gentlemen, excuse the warmth of my constitution.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Come, come, my Lord—be more tranquil—the old English constitution was not disturb'd in this manner; besides, I dare say, things are but half so bad as they are related; for I make no doubt but the Captain saw double the whole time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: But, Mr. Loveless—Sir, you who are a man of gallantry; think of the hardship of a beautiful young woman, taught—hem! hem!—taught prudence by an old fellow just at the very last moment—hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Arrah now, my dear Lord, it will be your last moment, if you put yourself into these passions about the women—for my part, I always advise following the ladies without any passion at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: The coolest advice, Captain, I ever heard in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
Gentlemen, excuse me—you see I'm overcome by the difficulty of—hem! hem!—a constitu∣tional
warmth—but your leave for a while—pray make free with every thing in my house—hem!—my sister and Miss Penelope will be glad to be treated without cere∣mony!—hem!—but, hem!—Zounds!—I'll revenge this prudery by ruining the whole sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: (calling after him) Upon my shoul the sex won't have much to fear—they can ruin your Lordship much easier. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Well, Loveless—do you not think your er∣rors more venial, when you see such characters as Lord Hectic's—libertines against nature, and vicious without even the excuses of inclination?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: No, my friend, I am too incorrigible in my repentance to receive any consolation from the follies of others—nay more, do you know that I am Quixote enough in virtue to wish that Lord Hectic may be dis∣appointed in his schemes, and even to feel interested that he should?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: I too am a convert to your sentiments,—my friend's continued dejection, while it grieves my heart▪ corrects it.—I look upon the atchievements of gallantry with less ardor than heretofore; and I can conceive it full as inglorious to rob youth and innocence of its peace, as to pilfer the property of my neighbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Can you then wonder at my sensibility for this ill-fated fair one?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Poor Louisa!—did you but know her▪ you would indeed be interested in her favour.—A beautiful young widow▪ left with an infant child, in circumstances the most humiliating.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: What then, she is really a woman of cha∣racter, whose afflictions are her only crimes?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Upon my word, Loveless, I believe so—I have often seen and convers'd with her at Sir Gregory's;
and I confess, in spite of my natural levity, I always respected the sadness that seem'd to weigh her down.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Then, Belcour, if such is her situation, it would be criminal even to suffer any aggravation of her misfortunes;—to be a passive spectator of the distress we can alleviate, is unpardonable in any man—but it is cowardice in the extreme to remain unmov'd, when the virtuous sorrows of an afflicted woman demand our assistance. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
An old castle, battlements, bastions, &c. in whimsical man∣ner; an old moat, and a draw-bridge; a great gun at the entrance.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter COLONEL QUORUM from the castle, with a book under his arm; PICKAXE following.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: And have you the confidence to say, that the lady said nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: And please your worship, what could she say better? for I mention'd every thing that was to be said in your honour's favour.—Ma'am, says I—you don't know what you hesitate about—a great justice, and a good officer—understands the rules of the army—and has written a book about law—not very young indeed—but then has a flashy appearance—never in a passion in his whole life.—Such a temper, there's no describing it.—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Ay, Pickaxe, you were right to say, I was of a mild disposition—it goes a great way with the ladies—and as for the men—death and fury! I should like to see him who durst deny it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P:
I am sure I am not the man to do it—sub∣mission
provokes nobody, as I say—so your honour can't be angry with me—but, if I might be so bold to advise—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Stop! I never take advice but on the parade, or at the quarter-sessions—there, indeed—on the bench a justice may submit to counsel—but, zounds! I flatter myself I can attack and subdue the ladies without any advice at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: And the sooner you do both the better; for I heard it whisper'd, as how Madam Louisa was about to leave the country—ah, your honour, tho' she affects to take on, and to hold herself up—all is not as it should be.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Hold herself up!—I like her the better for it—I'll tell you what, Pickaxe, as the attendant of wealth and prosperity, there is nothing so insulting as pride; but, in more humble fortune, it supports the cha∣racter: and, damn me, may I never swear an oath, if I shall not be more flatter'd with her affection, shou'd I find her pride the only support she has;—so I'm deter∣min'd to marry her immediately. (Going.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Stop, stop, your honour, indeed you had better ask her consent fist.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Don't provoke me—I tell you she must, she shall, consent▪ besides, has not she given me a thousand proofs of her regard? Didn't she look over my prayer-book last Sunday at church; and smile, be∣cause I chanc'd to open it at matrimony?—I'm con∣vinc'd she has a great stock of tenderness for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Aye, your worship—I hope it's not a laugh∣ing stock—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: For shame, Pickaxe—did not she shed a tear the other day, when I hinted that love often made the best of us unhappy.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Yes, yes; the women can laugh and cry just when they please, a I say to my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Pickaxe, don't put me in a passion—Zounds and fire! she shall have me—why, I tell you, I have order'd the lawyer to attend me with the writings—and there's no stopping the law; that will have its course—what the devil am I to do?—I say she must—I say he will—oh, here he comes.

DIV3.P: Master Janus you are as punctual—

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes; as punctual as a subpoena—here are the writings finely copied out. Very handsome provision indeed on your part—but said lady, whoever she is—left a blank for her name—said lady seems not to have much property.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Ah! that's neither here nor there.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Well, Colonel, if said lady is willing, as the law supposes she is, we have nothing to do but to put her in instead of the blank: favour me, if you please, with her description, spinster or widow, and residing in what parish—come, we can settle the business imme∣diately.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Zounds! Master Janus, you are the only lawyer I ever knew in my life in a hurry to settle any business, except his bill: what signifies where and what the lady is?—probably she has no parish—perhaps she has—perhaps I may chuse to marry—and perhaps I don't chuse to marry at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Very true.—I remember a case, George the 1st. Strange's Reports, folio 22, page 231—if A. will marry B.—and B refuses.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: What the devil have I to do with A. being refused?—nobody has refused me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe▪
SP.P: No, to be sure—why these are strange re∣ports indeed, Master Janus.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Just the case I was putting; for Coke very justly observes, that nobody can be married without their consent—for, says he, though the lady may be com∣manded after, she can't be commanded before;—and, ac∣cording to Magna Charta—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: According to the devil!—What, am I not one of the Bench, and don't I understand Magna Charta, and Burn's Justice, and all that, as well as you? Blood and confusion! am I to be instructed in the law of the land, and in the practice about women, at my time of life, by a pettifogging attorney?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Dear Colonel, I hope no offence—but you desired me to draw up your marriage settlement, and here it is: how should I imagine you wanted to conceal the lady's name? Besides, the law knows no concealment, except in its practice.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Why you poor, paltry, upstart, ill∣looking bit of black letter, how dare you approach a man of consequence, like me, with such language? Do you recollect who I am?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Why, if you mean to insult me, I do recollect who you are. I know you are half a justice, half a sol∣dier—that you strut about with a cockade in your hat, and a law-book under your arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Go on, Sir—You are but an attorney, and therefore would disgrace the vengeance of my arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, an old gentleman too, that fancies him∣self in love, and thinks he is going to be married—sends for an honest attorney to draw up the settlement—and then don't know who he is to be married to.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Zounds and damnation!—but I won't swear—as I am cool, perfectly cool; but if I was not—fire and destruction! I'd break every bone about you, and convert your skin into some of your own parch∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: I wish you wou'd—I shou'd like nothing bet∣ter, as the law observes, than to see a very fine action written upon my back.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Why you little rag of a remnant of the law you—I would have said rascal, but I know what you want, and shall only call you an attorney.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: That's enough: mind, you call'd me a rascal—at least you thought as much—and I'll do for you at the next assizes—Nisi prius is the word—Call an attorney a rascal, indeed! [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (in a violent passion) Here's impudence with a vengeance! the limbs of law rebelling against the body of justice—and yet there's no demanding satisfac∣tion.—By all the—

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Pray, your worship, forget your indignation—considr you're a soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Colonel Quorum.
SP.P: I do; and therefore, blood and fury! I will be reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Yes, but your honour, being a magistrate, you know, must act according to law.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (softening) True, Pickaxe, so I must—therefore I'll consult the Attorney General.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: It's a shame that a gentleman bearing his Majesty's commission should be so treated.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (heated) Zounds! bring me my nine∣inch pistols.

SP.SPEAKER: Pickaxe.
SP.P: Lord, your worship! I meant his Majesty's commission of the peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Well considered, Pickaxe—so take down the Statutes at Large, and follow me with them imme∣diately. [Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: BELCOUR.
SP.P: WELL, Loveless, convinc'd by your arguments, I have at length summon'd resolution enough to write a farewell letter to Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Believe me, Belcour, you will applaud your∣self for every resolution which tends to secure your honour and your peace.—An unworthy conquest wou'd have given you a thousand times more real sorrow, than even the surrender of your dearest wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Very likely;—but, upon my oul, I find it much less difficult to give advice than to take it.—I per∣suaded you to forget your Julia with great courage; but I cannot forsake this little gipsey of my own, without a thousand pangs that I blush to shew you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: In that case, my dear friend, why forget her at all?—My advice was to forego a guilty, not an honest pursuit.—Sacrifice to a worthy and ingenuous passion the false suggestions of pride; and meet the contemptible scoffs of the ignorant and unfeeling with the real feli∣city of having satisfied your own heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: And so I would—but consider my situation—I shall incur the certain displeasure of my uncle, and the relinquishing of all his possessions.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P:
And what have I gain'd by the attainment of mine? What joys have wealth and splendour brought to me?—an unhappy union with a woman, whose only merits they were—and a base desertion of another, whose
ingenuous modesty and native charms ever would have fix'd my heart—“whose tenderness and faithful love, wou'd have endear'd to me life's active day, and sweetly solaced its declining years.”

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: O! spare me, Loveless—spare us both;—a thousand mes have I reproach'd myself with writing the letter I sent this morning—but I trust to her generosity even against myself—she will not wish me, I think, to sa∣crifice—

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: If you look upon it as a sacrifice, Belcour, I have done; I wou'd not wish her to pass her days with a man who might possibly suffer them to be embittered by regret. So let us turn our thoughts to her poor friend Louisa; there, perhaps, our endeavours may be of some service. For love, that seems to be a foe to both of us, shall there give place to friendship's surer joys.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: How unfortunate it is that I have not yet been able to discover the place of her retreat!—I know not whom to apply to, for now I have no Harriet to inform me, should she even be acquainted with it herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Can't you dispatch some person to learn in what manner she left Sir Gregory's house, and whither she retired to?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Stay, stay; if I am not mistaken, here comes one who can give us the best information—'tis she—'tis Anna.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: O dear, good Mr. Belcour—pray Sir—a word if you please.—But I beg this gentleman's pardon for be∣ing so bold.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Speak, Anna—how does Louisa?—where is your mistress?—I have been searching for her far and near, and was this moment lamenting that I had not been able to find out her retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P:
Ah, like enough; like enough—but times are sadly altered with us since you last saw my lady at Sir
Gregory's—but I suppose, as you visit Miss Harriet every day, you know all about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: (confused) Indeed I do not—nor have I been there lately.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: No!—Well, sure that's wonderful—pray don't think me impertinent before this gentleman—but I hope you have a regard for that young lady, as I am sure she has for you; for I have often seen her shed a power of tears, when my dear mistress only said it was possible you might forsake her.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: (confused) Did she indeed shed tears?—But you don't answer our enquiries.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, we have had a sad change: and I know you wou'd pity my poor lady, and her sweet little boy too—if she leaves him, I shall be the only friend he has on earth; and my friendship, God help me! sig∣nifies little.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (emphatically) Where is the child?—bring me to him—while I live he shall not want a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Well, indeed, now you are very kind; for something my lady has just heard determin'd her to leave this part of the country immediately.—She had, indeed, thought of taking a journey before, but now she talks of never seeing me again.—O Mr. Belcour! you and Miss Harriet were her friends—pray endeavour to prevent her going—I'm sure I can never bear to part with so kind and good a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Nor shall you part with her, if my inter∣ference can be of use.—My friend Loveless too shall join his entreaties to mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Loveless!—sure▪ Sir, I think I have heard my lady mention such a name.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: My name!—heard your mistress mention my name!—impossible—I never was in this country before.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P:
Well, then, perhaps I was mistaken; for I have heard her mention it but once, to complain of some such
person—I suppose it was a relation who had used her ill—for indeed she has met with a great many enemies, and I am sure she never deserv'd one.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Let us then haste to rescue her from further distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Ah! Sir!—you are very good—perhaps you have a lady and children of your own, that you love and cherish, and who have never known what it is to want a husband and a father.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (to Belcour) O, Belcour, what pang is so severe as artless nature's undesign'd rebuke?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Come, Anna, inform us where Louisa resides, that we may endeavour to reconcile her to her fortune and her friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: You'll find my poor lady at the white cottage, near Colonel Quorum's, by the wood-side; but (I ask pardon for being so bold) I am afraid my mistress will not chuse to receive a visit from a stranger, though she may from Mr. Belcour.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, Anna—be assured we will neither of us impertinently intrude—but I feel moved at her distress; exasperated against the authors of it; and, as far as friendship allows, I am determined to protect her in∣fant and herself. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
An apartment in LORD HECTIC'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter LADY BETTY WORMWOOD, with a letter in her hand.
DIV3.P:
Well, this is charming—who would have suspected it? Here have I found the copy of a love-letter addressed to Colonel Quorum—from the prudent Miss Penelope Zodiac, who never descends to contemplate that impro∣per
creature, a man—It seems an answer to one received from him.—The blooming maiden scorns heroics, and breathes her passion in the simple language of nature.

LETTER.P: You request an interview—can I refuse it to a gentleman in whom I have mak'd an amiable repugnance towards the ordinary class▪ of females, and whose conceptions, I am led to think, move in a higher sphere? Come, then, let us enjoy together a scientific communion of sentiment, in a calm exposition of the nobler faculties.

DIV3.P: Well, here's the art of love turned into science, for the sake of Colonel Quorum—one of the oldest scholars I know of. I dare say, now, if she was here, she would deny her own hand-writing. There's nothing I detest so much, as saying first one thing and then another.—Here she comes, a hypocritical creature.—My dearest friend, I have been languishing for you this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I too, my lady, have quitted my studies some time, in hopes to enjoy a little relaxed intercourse. But (cautiously) I hope we are not overheard—for, be∣twixt ourselves, I have made a little discovery that con∣cerns you.—You know my talent—I had always a head for finding out secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: True, Miss Penelope—I have a head for finding out secrets too—You indeed are too prudent to let any body discover your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P:
Yes, I believe no person is more dis∣creet—but to the point—You must know then, my dear Lady Betty, that odious woman, that Louisa, on being
dismissed from Sir Gregory's, has had the confidence to seat herself by Colonel Quorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: By Colonel Quorum!—Ah! I suppose she thought herself safe by the side of justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: But she shall find herself mistaken—You shall not be imposed upon in that manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I imposed upon, Miss Pen!—Don't be uneasy on that head—believe me, I see through the whole design.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Besides too, the Colonel is a mighty good sort of a man, and should not be led astray by so artful a minx as she is.—I cannot help disliking her, merely on your account.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I perceive you can't—and am exceedingly obliged to you for the warmth you express merely on my account: but, though you wish me to be apprehensive for Colonel Quorum, upon my word I don't see the necessity for it, as I dare say he has not the least regard for any female living.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Not of a light sort, I dare be sworn—though I cannot believe he would be insensible to proper attractions—“”a prudent, reserved manner, and a scien∣tific mind.—But, after all, who knows what this for∣ward hussey may do?

DIV3.Q:
“”
Lady Betty.
True, indeed; should she venture to write to him, she might consent to an interview—but that is not likely—No woman, you know, Miss Pen. could possibly think of writing to a man for such a purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: "Miss Penelope.
SP.P: (smothering her vexation) Aye—“why yes, writing to a gentleman, as you say, with improper ideas—no lady could think of.”—I hope she knows nothing of my letter. (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P:
Yes, I was certain you would agree with me—however the Colonel, I believe, might be trusted:
I dare say he would laugh at any woman that was guilty of such an indiscretion—don't you think he would?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Laugh! why, no.—I mean—yes, cer∣tainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Lord, Miss Penelope, what is the matter? You seem interested about the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I interested about a man! Heaven for∣bid! I was only thinking of that Jezabel.—As for the Colonel, I believe he has too just notions of what is beco∣ming, for your Miss to spoil.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: My Miss, Miss Penelope! You know I hate Misses—your Colonel, I apprehend you would say.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Mine, Lady Betty! I beg you would not insinuate that I have a Colonel, or that I would quit the sublime meditations for any Colonel upon earth; therefore, Ma'am, I insist upon it you will not Colonel me. (walks about in a passion)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Dear Ma'am, I beg ten thousand pardons.—Indeed I could not have imagined I should have affected you so much—and, had I known your attachment to Colonel Quorum, I am sure I should have been the last person in the world to have mentioned it—for I hate be∣ing ill-natured, you know I do.—I am glad I have pu∣nished her hypocrisy. (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Ladies, may I intreat permission to intrude?—I come in behalf of distress, to plead a female cause, and sue to you for pity:—I am told, Lady Betty, you know the unfortunate Louisa, and are not ignorant of what she has suffered from your brother's pursuits. Might I request you to be her friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P:
Her friend! Me to be her friend! Indeed I detest ill-nature, and never say an unkind word of any
body—otherwise I could not suppose you would have asked me such a thing for so worthless an object;—I am not, however, the person to expose my own sex, though, to be sure—one cannot help making distinctions.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Ah, Lady Betty! And it is those cruel dis∣tinctions, which they who have fortunately never trans∣gressed are too apt to make, that bar the entrance of virtuous society, and cut off the faint hope of repentant error. But here, I understand, there is no cause for this severity.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: O to be sure not, Mr. Loveless! And so you think there is no occasion for ladies to know any thing of erudition, and logarithms, and trigonometry—they need do nothing but go about making love, and dreaming of the sensations—oh fie!—If she does not know how a lady ought to conduct herself properly, let her read Plutarch's Lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: But, Madam, if I am rightly informed, the conduct of Louisa is not so reproachable.—Nay, Madam, I am told there is a very respectable gentleman in the neighbourhood, a Colonel Quorum, who has made her an offer of his hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: (alarmed, and attempting to conceal it) Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: (astonished) Really!—Colonel Quorum offer her his hand!—Well, if some people can forget what others have done, and treat them like proper people, for my part I never can be ill-natured enough not to rejoice at it.—And I dare say Miss Penelope Zodiac will be en∣tirely of my opinion. (sneering)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Pray—Mr. Loveless—Sir—I really speak out of regard for the lady—what was the result of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: As I understand, Madam, she civilly and modestly declined it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I wish she had taken him at his word.—I speak out of regard to the lady too—

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: On this account then, though perhaps in an inferior situation, she is entitled to every respect.—If Lord Hectic therefore has an unconquerable passion, why not rise above common prejudices, and make her an offer of his hand!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Sir!—My brother make Louisa an offer of his hand!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: (turning to her) And really, Lady Betty, as my Lord is such a libertine—I mention it for the sake of his morals—I do not think he can do better than reform by marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: And pray, Miss Penelope, who made you a judge, as an unmarried lady, of marriage, and refor∣mation?—You, whose head is alwaysamong the poles?—You should not find fault, I am sure, whose disposition is so much in the milky way.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Lord, Lady Betty! I believe I find fault as little as other ladies, who know no more of delicacy and metaphysics than the Great Mogul.—A widow, a mere widow!—"next kin to an impure." (walking about angrily.)

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Ladies, I beg ten thousand pardons—I really had no intention of offending; and am exceedingly con∣cern'd to see you both so angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Angry, Mr. Loveless! I don't know what you mean!—I can assure you I am not angry—not at all angry; but I know when to be displeased, as well as other people.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: And you, Miss Zodiac—your philosophy at least—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: —Pray, Sir, don't tantalize me—I know when a lady ought to be a philosopher, and when she ought to lay her philosophy aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: But, Lady Betty—should Lord Hectic himself be inclined to marry her—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I beg, Sir, you will put no such indecency into his head.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Why, Col. Quorum has absolutely offer'd himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Impossible!—I am sure he has a better taste for the sublime and beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: A peer of the realm give his hand to a wanton!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: A soldier disgrace his arms with an ignoramus!

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Let me entreat you, ladies, to be more candid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Some folks are always intermeddling where they have no business.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Yes, endeavouring to steer, without knowing a point of the compass.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Impertinent intrusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Totally in the dark, as to the effect of causes.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Nay, ladies, I have done—I came hither to appeal to your tenderness, not to awaken your resent∣ment.—I simply imagin'd the misfortunes of an unhappy woman wou'd have found an advocate in every female breast—but I am now convinc'd that pride is far superior to humanity, and science soars too high to have any know∣ledge of the trifling feelings of nature.—Ladies, your obedient. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Meddling creature!—I wish he was mar∣ried a second time, for his pains.—My dear friend, Miss Penelope, that the men should imagine they could pro∣voke us!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P:
True, my dear friend, Lady Betty—I do flatter myself that a knowledge of the spheres, and an
insight into the heavenly motions, prevent me from all earthly provocations at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Certainly—I knew you cou'd not be so ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: And I was sure you cou'd not be ill∣natured.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I never could be ill-natured in my life—So let's lose no time in contriving some how or other to ruin this troublesome woman, and drive her out of the neighbourhood. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
A Room hung with Maps, old Pedigrees, and Coats of Arms, with an old Banner over them, in Sir Gregory's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter LORD HECTIC hastily, the Captain following after∣wards; Sir GREGORY with one Hand behind him, the other up to his Nose—at a slow solemn step.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Don't make any excuses to me, Sir Gregory;—you a courtier, and forget what is due to a peer, and a man of consequence!—Heh' Captain?
SP.STAGE: (turning to Swagger, who keeps at his back.)

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Aye—who has a captain to back him be∣fore and behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: A man of nice feelings, and strong powers. (coughing)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Be calm, my Lord—pray be calm—and a little more ceremonious, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Don't talk to me of clmness and cere∣mony—don't you see that I'm in a violent passion—Heh' heh'!

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
