SP.P: O fait, and so am I, my dear—without any ceremony at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P:
It can't be, my Lord—the thing is im∣possible—a peer can't be in a passion—never was such a
thing heard of, except in the House; there, indeed, vio∣lence is a virtue, and he may say any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Don't tell me of saying any thing—when I am absolutely dumb at your incivility, Sir Gre∣gory.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: I guilty of incivility!—Place and prece∣dence, my Lord—but it is impossible.—Beau Nash him∣self durst not have made such a charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O' my conscience then, you call turning a lady out of your house no incivility at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: What say you to that, Sir Gregory?—do you think Beau Nash wou'd have done so?

P.Q: “”Fie, my Lord—the old court never cared who was turned out.—I should blush to see your lordship uneasy at the dismission of any thing under a maid of honour—and they are not what they used to be neither.

DIV3.Q:
“”
Lord Hectic.
Psha! Sir Gregory, don't plague me about old maids of honour; give me a modern one—hem!—but have you no respect for the affections of a man of fashion?

“”
Sir Gregory.
Certainly nothing pleases me more than to see a man of fashion in love, in a gallant and gentleman-like manner. But then I expect forms; no clandestine visits in my house. When a proper equi∣page is prepared—a number of out-riders—with an avant-courier—his lordship's chaplain attending—due notice given—and approbation asked—no man more ready in his place than Sir Gregory Glovetop—at the head of the great stairs, in point ruffles and clock'd stockings.

“”
Lord Hectic.
What the devil, didst thou expect that I should have visited a lady with a dozen out-riders and a chaplain? acquainted all my servants that I had a
love affair upon my hands, (coughing) and brought my whole household to partake of it?

“”
Swagger.
O yes; Sir Gregory thinks there can't be too many to partake of a good thing.

“”
Lord Hectic.
Besides, didst thou imagine a beautiful creature would not be pleased with a private meeting,—There's nothing the women are so fond of as se∣crets.

SP.SPEAKER: "Sir Gregory.
SP.P: My Lord, there should be no secrets “out of the cabinet; and there indeed—but I am silent.” Pray, gentlemen, be cool—If Sir Clement was alive, he could only ask pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: And don't you expect that I should lay such a piece of family ruins in ashes, as a punishment for your audacity?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: My Lord, I hope you will not forget your rank.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O, fait, and I have no rank to forget—So as you have been so rude to the young lady, be civil to the gentleman, and give us satisfaction immediately. (ad∣ancing nearer)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: I could not break through forms for the universe.—Single combat, to be sure, may be maintained, but always with proper decorum. You state your grie∣vances—I reply—preliminaries are broken—and then war is declared in due course.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Devil burn me, but we'll do as the French do—declare war without saying a syllable of the matter. So come on, Sir Gregory—By St. Patrick, I'll bother both sides of your ears with nothing but war! war! (bel∣lowing).

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P:
Peace, I say, or I'll read the riot act—
Gentlemen, your most obedient.—And now, what is the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: The matter is, Colonel, that I believe your coming has saved my life—though I cannot ap prove of this entrance into my house without ceremony, for all that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: What signifies how we came into the house, when you've turned out the most beautiful—the most exquisite—hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: I know it all—the most accomplish'd Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: To be sure, Colonel:—Egad, I thought you had taste enough to be of my opinion.—What a charming appendage she would have made in the suite of a man of fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (astonished) My Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Yes, she would have been a very sweet appendage to us all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Love, Colonel, without the galling chains of marriage—a companion for the time being, and a temporary addition to my domestic joys—hem! hem!—besides, she should have retired on a pension from the fatigues of gallantry.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Well, by my knighthood, nobody could have said that but a courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: And is it possible that you can be talking about the divine Louisa in this manner?—I swear that she is purer than innocence itself.—Death and deso∣lation! was it you, Sir Gregory, who said any thing to the prejudice of Louisa's character?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: I talk of character, and bred at court, Colonel! how could you imagine such a thing? I who was always called Anti-Scandal by the ladies of the bed∣chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Then, zounds, Sir! I suppose it was you who dared to hold an opinion to the prejudice of the most charming of her sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O! by no means.—Upon my shoul, and I have no opinion of her at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Then you alone, my Lord, must an∣swer for this defamation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Not I, indeed; I never answer for any thing.—To be sure, I do think her handsome—hem! hem!—as every man of gallantry ought—and may have paid her a few little attentions, perfectly innocent as yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: By Heaven I believe so—but men of your lordship's turn are apt to forget, that in the eyes of the sober part of the world, those innocent attentions have the appearance of criminality, and the offer of them is sometimes as fatal as the success.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Very sententious and moral, egad!—but really, Colonel, do you expect that a man of fashion, in the heyday of youth and spirits—hem! hem!—as I am, can be stopt, in his pursuit of beauty, by a lecture on morality?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: A lecture on blood and vengeance, my Lord!—for know, when those pursuits happen to be directed against the innocence which boasts a protector, balls and bombardments! that protection which my arm affords her must first be defeated.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: (stalking about) I swear, by Sir Philip Sydney, the old court reviv'd again.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: A challenge, as I'm a peer!—hem! hem!—but I take no advantages, Colonel; and for once you shall escape being brought upon your knees before the House for a breach of privilege.—The Captain, however, lays under no such impediment; and, being a plebeian quarrel, may enter into it with propriety.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (advancing to the Captain) Well, Sir, what have you to say?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Upon my soul, Colonel, nothing at all: the very sight of a justice always binds me over to keep the peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: My Lord—I blush to think that a no∣bleman, who dares wantonly sport with the character of a woman, should tremble to defend what he is not afraid to assert.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Don't provoke me, Colonel—I'm a very passionate man, I assure you.—Stand between us, Captain Swagger.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Not I, my Lord—I'm a very passionte man too.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Contemptible evasion!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Pray don't irritate me any longer—I really may forget my rank.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Zounds and the devil!—my lord chief justice himself would be forced to swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: (interposing) Pray, Colonel, be patient: consider what privileges noblemen are entitled to.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Come along, Captain—I'm indifferent about myself; you, however, have been ill treated, and I'll think of your wrongs with proper resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Fait, and that's very kind—but, if your ordship pleases, we'll forget them both as soon as we can. Mind, Colonel, if I should remember this treat∣ment—I bear no malice, because I told you I had forgot∣ten it. [Exeunt both.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Bravo, Colonel! A second Marlborough, as I live.—No one enemy dare stand before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P:
I don't know that, Sir Gregory.—Can I call those my friends who have treated Louisa un∣kindly? and are not you in that number? A lady for whom I have the most profound regard, and who I have
some reason to think—but no matter.—However I did expect you would—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Don't expect me, Colonel, to negotiate any private treaties; I must be public ambassador, or nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: So you shall—so you shall—and pray lose no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: Don't hurry me▪

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (impetuously) Zounds, Sir Gregory—fly this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: (calmly) Can't fly—no air balloon ex∣ploits for me. [Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
A Wood. LOUISA'S Cottage at a Distance.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter LOUISA in a great agitation, looking back as she advances.
DIV3.P: 'TIS impossible!—It could not be Loveless, that I discovered just now in the wood—base, per∣fidious man!—cruelly as he has treated me, he wou'd not come hither to insult the misery he has occasioned.—No, 'tis not in nature to be so inhuman;—besides, he is wholly ignorant of my situation.—“My eyes have cer∣tainly deceiv'd me; and my tortur'd mind, still sadly bent on former scenes, pictures resemblances where none exist.—Yes, dear fatal copy (taking out a picture) of him who once possessed my virgin heart; in whose false bosom all my fondest hopes were centered; and whose delusive form, in spite of all my wrongs, I can∣not tear from my remembrance—let me examine thee again.”—Whoever he was, he seem'd, as I thought, in earnest discourse with Mr. Belcour—they are not yet come out from the wood—I'll endeavour to steal softly through the thicket unobserved, and get a nearer view.

Ah! whither shall I run?—'Tis he! 'tis the barbarous, unrelenting spoiler.—Oh! unfeeling Loveless!—After having invaded the innocence of my youth; driven me from my native, peaceful home; deprived me of a fa∣ther's fond protection; and exposed me, and your help∣less
infant, to all the miseries of want and shame, of per∣secution and contempt—you come, to complete the mea∣sure of your guilt, to rob us of the only little shed that's left us; to triumph o'er our complicated woes, and sport with agony unutterable.—Ye gracious Powers! to what am I reduc'd!—My poor brain will turn.—“But per∣haps I do him injustice,—perhaps he feels.—O! no; I will not see him—I will not endure his pity—when I must despise his heart. (Starts.) Heavens!—he advances—where, where shall I retreat to?—Alas! the world affords me now no place to hide in!”—I'll fly then—beg, starve, do any thing, rather than bear the presence of a man I ought for ever to detest—(Runs, looking back, then stops) but see, they separate; and Mr. Belcour approaches alone.—I will endeavour to compose myself—shou'd he be informed of my situation, he will have learned, at least, that intentional guilt has never caused these tears to flow.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Forgive, Madam, my freedom, in thus break∣ing in upon your retirement: but let me hope the motive may plead for its excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (hesitating) Mr. Belcour's conduct, I flatter myself, will never need excuse. I thought I saw you with another gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, with my friend, Mr. Loveless.—He wanted much to offer his good services; but, being a stranger, wou'd not venture so far without permission; he has therefore retired for the present.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I am easy again. (aside)—Mr. Belcour, I thank you for your attention—but, at present, solitude is what I seek for.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
I am aware, Madam, you may feel a re∣pugnance in committing your cares to one so little con∣nected with you as myself—but be assured, tho' only an acquaintance, I feel all the sympathy of friendship; and,
knowing the story of your griefs, wish sincerely to remove them.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (alarm'd) Then I am lost indeed! (aside) What, Sir, has the gentleman, Mr. Loveless—has he communicated any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Mr. Loveless communicated, Madam!—my friend Loveless, as a man of probity and feeling, is, in∣deed, interested in your cause;—but he knows your suf∣ferings only from report, nor has he communicated any thing that can give you uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I beg pardon, Mr. Belcour, for the suppo∣sition.—But I know the ill-nature of the world, and I thought something might have been said—that the gentle∣man you were with might—but perhaps I am mis∣taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Indeed, Madam, if you knew my friend as I do—were you acquainted with the goodness of his heart, and the tenderness of his nature, you would be sensible of the high opinion he entertains of your desert.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I hold myself obliged for the good opinion of every one.—But, Sir, we find ourselves sometimes de∣ceived—appearances are not—however it is not for me to be interested about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Believe me, he reprobates Lord Hectic's con∣duct as much as myself; and both of us feel for the in∣convenience it has subjected you to.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O Mr. Belcour! I have too long walked hand in hand with sorrow, to feel much concern for any incon∣venience;—Lord Hectic has been troublesome to me, I own, but he is not the man that I am most apprehensive of.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Come, Madam, assure yourself I am your friend—I see Lord Hectic's conduct has involved you in distress;—indeed I blush for the unworthiness of his sen∣timents.—Allow me the task of undeceiving him as to
your character, and onvincing him of the impropriety of his pursuits.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Mr. Belcour, if my Lord Hectic's sentiments were an object of consideration, there is no one I would more gladly employ in that task than yourself;—to be sure every woman of sensibility must feel for injurious suspi∣cions;—but I have learned the lesson of submission; and, while I thank you for your attention, Sir, believe me when I assure you my distresses are of such a nature, that even your kindness can give me no relief.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: To be sure, Madam, my fortune at present is narrow, tho' my good wishes towards you are unbound∣ed;—but I am certain Mr. Loveless, whose mind is en∣larged as his circumstances are ample, will gladly supply every deficiency.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Excuse me, Sir—want of fortune is not what I allude to;—but were it so, and rigid penury now stared me in the face,—nothing shou'd induce me to apply there for succour.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Were you acquainted with my friend, I am certain you wou'd alter your opinion;—his desire to serve you is founded on the noblest principles,—for he is a man, Madam, who, softened by misfortunes of his own, is alive only to the calamity of others.—He has conversed with your servant Anna; has seen your little boy, is charmed with his artless looks and infant prattle; and has commissioned me to request you would commit the care of his youth, and the establishment of his fortune, to his protection and regard.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Did he take notice of my boy?—O nature, how powerful is thy force!—The mother at this moment almost cancels all the past (aside)—Exeuse these tears, Sir;—a parent's grateful tribute for her only child.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Yes, Madam, your son too was equally struck with his attention—sat on his knee, threw his
little arms about his neck—embraced him—called him fa∣ther, and said that you wou'd thank him for them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O Sir!—Your description is more than I can support.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Shall I bring Mr. Loveless to you, Madam? I can easily overtake him, and he will repeat in person the sentiments that do honour to his heart. (going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O, no, Sir—not for the world—I cou'd not bear it.—For myself, my sojourn here will be but short—for my child, tell him 'tis his—I bequeath him to his care: may he regard him with a parent's fondness, and may my boy return it with a filial duty!

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: Louisa in close conference with Mr. Belcour!

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Rest assured, Madam, that your interest will always be near my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: (aside.) Heavens! what do I hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (weeping.) Forgive, Mr. Belcour, that af∣fliction which my situation naturally produces;—I must leave this place for ever—I feel too for Harriet, I know she loves me, and I fear her gentle heart will break—in∣deed I am grateful for your attentions; but it is on a sub∣ject on which you will not take it amiss if I endeavour to conceal my tears. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: I conjure you, Madam, to allow me—to hear me. By Heaven there is a something in that woman that interests me—I must follow her, and endeavour to persuade her to look for happier days. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P:
(coming forward) Can I believe my senses?—can that be Louisa?—the partner of my bosom, who shar'd my confidence—to whose sorrows I gave all my pity?—This then was the story she could not reveal to me without blushing; well might she avoid my en∣quiries—the cause of Belcour's unkind letter to me is now
fully explained;—Louisa was the sacrifice he could not make—ah! treacherous friend! If such is the treatment we are to expect from those we most esteem, where shall our affections be placed? [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
An Apartment in LORD HECTIC'S House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady BETTY WORMWOOD, followed by JANUS.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: But now, my dear Mr. Janus, you know my regard for propriety; and therefore, notwithstanding I cannot help feeling for the unhappy wretches of my own sex, yet we must have this creature, who has capti∣vated my brother's affections, removed out of the neigh∣bourhood, no matter how, and I shall depend upon your ingenuity for doing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (bowing) True, my Lady—Burn, in his chap∣ter about nuisances, does mention the women; but I don't recollect he says they can be removed whether they will or no—can your Ladyship remember a case in point?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Pooh! Mr. Janus, how should I remem∣ber cases?—I want your assistance; and you must stretch a point as far as you can, to oblige me.—The law, you know, is a wide field.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: It is so, my Lady—it is so—and I don't mind going a little about the edges of it;—but totally to tres∣pass might put me upon the Black List.—However, I'll look into the Attorney's Guide, and see what I can do.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Come, come, Mr. Janus, I know you are a man of integrity, and honest people have their scruples;—but here is the attorney's guide—take and examine it (giving him a purse);—and tho' you should act a little against (he puts out his hand to take it) the letter, yet, in equity, you wou'd undoubtedly be justified.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, your ladyship has set the matter in a new light.—I had forgot equity totally;—and really I can't help seeing it now in the light of a con∣spiracy against your brother.—I remember a case in the rebellion of forty-five—John Jones versus Sandy Maclean—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: (interrupting) True, true, good Mr. Janus—I perceive you begin to feel the weight of my argument—it certainly is a conspiracy against my bro∣ther's person, as well as his fortune; and therefore she must on no account be suffered to come near his house.—I think you see the case just as you should do—do me the favour of accepting this (gives a bank note).

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (taking it) Yes, yes, my Lady—I know where to put my finger; and you may rest assured, on the faith of an attorney, the plaintiff shall be nonsuited, and her cause kicked out of court—she shall never get into my Lord's house whilst I live, and in two days she shall be fifty miles from the place.—But hold, my Lady—there is one difficulty has just struck me—there is another attorney in the parish—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Well, Mr. Janus,—what of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Why, my Lady, I think we had better have him likewise. Two of us, I think, will finish the busi∣ness.—Suppose your Ladyship gives me his retaining fee.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Well, well, Mr. Janus—only spare my feelings, and get the jade removed by fair or foul means, and I shan't mind a little expence.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Oh! my Lady, two attornies!—only think of that, and you need not despair of any means whatever.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Soft—I see my brother coming this way—you must not mention my having been here for the world, or the subject of our discourse—only remember the business. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, yes, depend upon me—as I have mad sure of the principal evidence. (pocketing the purse)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Ha! my little attorney! what the devil art thou pocketing there so hastily—thy conscience?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (confused) No, my Lord, no—thank Heaven, I am not ashamed of my conscience—I only took the liberty of stepping in to enquire after your Lordship's health—I am delighted to see you look so charmingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: I dare say thou art—especially as thou wilt get nothing by my death.—But thou art come most luckily, my little vellum-blotter—for I want thy assist∣ance;—thou know'st the woman I was mentioning to thee the other day—

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, yes, my Lord, the lady that was at Sir Gregory Glovetop's—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: The same—hem! hem!—the thought of her warms me. Now I am told she is about to leave this country immediately—

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Really, my Lord—I am prodigiously sorry for it.—This is lucky!—I shall carry her ladyship's cause without bringing it to a trial. (Aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: But, as such a circumstance would anni∣hilate my hopes, that must be prevented immediately; and therefore thou must exert all thy ingenuity to keep her in the neighbourhood—

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: My Lord! to be sure, if your Lordship wishes it; but how can an attorney prevent a lady from follow∣ing her inclinations?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
Why, you must know, on her leaving that old fool, Sir Gregory, she has become, without know∣ing it, tenant to a little cottage of mine, which I learned this morning from my steward—and therefore, on some pretence or other, I would have such difficulties thrown
in the way, as may prevent her putting her design in execution.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Aye—payment of rent; which, being an ex∣ceeding neat house, may be exorbitant—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: True—then she may perhaps think of a personal application to me—I step in, and become her guardian angel at once.—You take the matter, heh?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, I remember a case—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Damn your cases—pocket that (throws a purse) and fly to execute my plan.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (going, and returns) I do.—She shall be safe in your Lordship's house in less than two hours—but, my Lord, the ladies of a family you know are a little in∣quisitive, sometimes—Now, as I have the honour of transacting business for your Lordship's sister, I hope she will not know a syllable of what I undertake for your Lordship—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Oh! I see thou art an honest fellow, and stand up for thy character.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: I do—I do, my Lord—My father always said I was too honest to thrive.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: In your profession he meant—but hold, is not there another honest gentleman of your calling in this parish?—You must take care that Louisa gets no ad∣vice about our proceedings—for I do not imagine they will be strictly legal.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Never fear him, I have him under my thumb here. (putting his hand on his pocket)—Besides, the gentle∣men in our way are very honourable, and never betray each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Then there's that fighting Colonel must be taken care of, for he's too honourable by half—and is such an old fool, that he actually wants to marry her, with his infirm constitution—Hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P:
Does he so?—Oh, oh! That's the blank he
wants to fill up, is it?—I am glad I shall be able to vex him—don't be afraid of his worship, my Lord—I have all my life been used to counteract justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Then lose not a moment, for I am all impatience to enjoy the fruits of thy industry;—and hem! hem!—the devil take this cough, I say. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: JANUS
SP.P: Well, this is a good morning's walk—to satisfy one's interest and one's revenge at the same time, by se∣curing the principal evidence on both sides the question—and I think we need not fear being cross-examined.—I am glad his lordship has employed me in this business, otherwise I must have obeyed her ladyship; but when one is engaged on both sides, one can satisfy one's con∣science, and take that which is most agreeable. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
Miss PENELOPE ZODIAC's Dressing-Room; she sitting at a Table, with a Letter in her Hand.
DIV3.P: I think this is the time Colonel Quorum requested an interview; and it would be exceedingly rude not to be punctual with military gentlemen.—Besides, with what a polite warmth he writes—“I die with impatience to thank you for your condescension, which I am now reading from your fair hand.”—Yes, yes, I certainly have struck him, notwithstanding the reports about that creature Louisa.—If he should press me, I must relent, however, with a proper cruelty.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Servant to announce the Colonel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Shew him in—shew him in.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P:
Dear Madam, forgive my eagerness to ex∣press
my sense of your kindness.—I should have address'd myself, in the first place, to Lady Betty, as having the honour of a greater intimacy; but Miss Penelope Zodiac has a heart as amiable as her person, and will forgive the intrusion of a soldier and a magistrate, who comes to her as a tender suppliant.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Lord, Colonel, you put me quite in a flutter.—I should be sorry to refuse Colonel Quorum any proper request—but—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Be not alarm'd, dear Miss Penelope.—Col. Quorum, I am bold to say, wou'd not abuse the kindness of any Lady; and you, Madam, will allow for the feelings of a man in love.—If I can but persuade her to interest herself for me with Louisa, it wou'd go a great way. (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Yes, I see how it is. (aside)—I beg, Sir, you will be seated (both sit):—and so, Colonel, I think you said you was in love.—Girls, indeed, are fond of coquetting—but a sensible woman scorns to give unneces∣sary pain.—I assure you I feel for your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Ah, Madam, you, who are so kind, wou'd pardon my warmth, if you were sensible of the charms of her whom I adore.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: O, Sir, I am afraid you do but flat∣ter me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Rather, Madam, say you flatter me—but, to be plain, tho' a friend to the sister, you may, perhaps, be ignorant of the libertine principles of Lord Hectic.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Truly, Colonel, I am no stranger to them.—Indeed I have often thought, though only a visitor, a kind of satellite, as I may call myself, in these regions, that I'm not entirely safe in the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: O Madam, you wou'd really be alarm'd, if you knew the designs he is capable of forming.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P:
How, Colonel!—you frighten me to
death.—I won't stay another night within his atmosphere.—Oh, Colonel, it is on these occasions a single lady wants most a protector.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: True, Madam;—and Col. Quorum▪ when he is not bound to keep the peace, does not want the spirit to protect any lady;—but how mortifying it wou'd be, if those efforts were disregarded, and his atten∣tions were of no avail! (in a tender accent.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: And cannot you, who are a soldier▪ read any thing from the eyes—the manner that approves, though it says nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: How good you are!—would you but deign to unite your interest with mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: O, Colonel, pray support me—I'm in a strange taking.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Dearest Madam, will you then consent to my proposal?—Will you espouse my cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Heavens!—how my heart beats.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (more earnest) Say, dearest Madam, that you will be the mistress of my fate on this oc∣casion.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Well, Colonel, I relent—I am yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (kissing her hand) I am transported—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: (looking tenderly) But will you be so always, when you become my husband, Colonel?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (starting up) Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Yes, Colonel, I see you are surprised at my kindness—perhaps some women would have been more cruel.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Dear Madam, I fear we misunderstand each other.—By Heaven I cannot but be sensible of the honour you have done me—but, in truth, my heart is en∣gaged to one in whose interest I hoped to have made you a partaker—the divine Louisa.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P:
(starting up) What! and have you been
deceiving me into a passion all this time, and seducing me into an unsuspected avowal of regard, merely to play upon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Dearest Madam—be pacified.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: And is it thus you impose upon young ladies?—Fie for shame.—You a soldier, and a justice!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: But, Miss Penelope, by all that's mili∣tary and legal, I am most heartily sorry for the mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Mistake, Sir! don't call it mistake—Did you not write to me?—Did you not talk of my fair hands?—Have you not, you audacious fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (in a passion) Zounds and perdition!—but I am temperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Sir, I insist upon your seeing me no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: I obey.—Military gentlemen seem born to distress the ladies—but, as a magistrate, I ought not to be a disturber of the peace. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Well, this is a shock indeed to my first passion, and requires all the philosophy I am mistress of.—But, thank Heaven, nobody knows it but myself.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
A small room in LOUISA'S cottage—a table, with paper, ink, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: LOUISA
SP.P:
When will relentless Fortune cease its persecutions▪ this is indeed a cruel aggravation of my sorrows (look∣ing at the letter) to be accused by my Harriet of having seduced the affections of her Belcour, whom, she tells me, she has lot for ever:—“to reproach me in terms the most resentful, and tear a bleeding bosom with the sharpest poignard of unkindness—yet I forgive her—
too well I know how severe a trial it is to lose that object on whom our first affections have been placed”—before I go, I will unfold to her my fatal story, and convince her how impossible it is that I, the child of woe, the victim of sensibility, could have been guilty of such baseness.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Madam, the chaise is ready—but, oh! my dear, my honoured lady—let me again entreat.—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Anna, I must leave you—I cannot however bear a formal parting—you know, and will remember my wishes—take my boy in your hand, and, together with this packet, wait upon Mr. Loveless.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Yes, my dear lady—but perhaps there will be no occasion—I met Mr. Loveless just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: What is it you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: Pray don't be angry with me—but he seemed so pressing, I told him where you lived, and he promis'd to call upon you directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (more alarmed) Promis'd to call upon me!

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: I hope, Madam, you are not offended—but indeed he was so kind to the child, and enquir'd so ten∣derly after you. (knocking at the door)—O Madam, there he is—and to be sure he is the civillest best gentleman—I am certain you'll be glad to see him. [runs out.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (greatly agitated) What now remains for me?—Fate thou hast done thy worst; the deepest woes, the purest intentions, could not avert thy rigour. I would have saved my child from shame—I would have sought my father's humble roof, and then in some obscure cor∣ner have implored his leave to linger out the little rem∣nant of my days—O nature support me—he is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Madam, your most obedient—I beg you will not be surpriz'd at my appearance—tho' I am a stranger, I'm quite a gentleman, I assure you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir, pray Sir—to what cause am I indebted for the honour of this visit?—I am indeed unacquainted with your person.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Perhaps so—but I believe I'm as well known at the quarter-sessions as most people—I have the honour to be an attorney, and to manage the concerns of my Lord Hectic—I think you are acquainted with his Lordship—he is a most amiable man, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: It may be so, Sir—but I hope you will not think me impertinent in saying, I have particular busi∣ness at present.—Should Loveless come—(aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: And so have I—I like business of all things, and do a great deal for his Lordship: no offence, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, be kind enough not to trouble me about Lord Hectic, or any other person.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Certainly not, Ma'am—never give trouble without shewing cause.—Really now this is a pretty gen∣teel house you have got into—very neatly furnish'd in∣deed—I dare say you must pay very handsomely for it—belongs, I think, to Lord Hectic;—no offence, I hope—but his Lordship is rather a punctual man, and apt to enquire about rents—never suffers a tenant to quit the premises till all is discharged.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Well, Sir, if this house does belong to Lord Hectic—of which I was ignorant, or, on many accounts, I should not have entered its doors—I have left orders to discharge faithfully all my debts—however there's what will satisfy you (offers him money) in the mean time, I beg you will no longer bar my passage. (going)

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (interrupting her) Dear Madam, I hope y will not think of it—besides, I can't give a proper re∣ceipt, I have no stamps—My Lord loves to settle these matters himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Sir, I insist upon freedom in my own house—I hope you will not think of stopping me—I beg, Sir, I may pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (stopping her) Yes, Madam—I remember a case—2d of Charles the Ist.—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O Heavens! if Loveless shou'd now enter! (aside)—What, Sir, is your breast incapable of sympa∣thy? Have you no compassion for the sorrows of an helpless female?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Aye, 2d of Charles the Ist.—as I said—there was a negro-woman that had got into a house—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Do you then mean to insult me? O Provi∣dence!—but I submit to thy decrees—and is there no one to feel for my affliction?

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, to be sure—wait upon Lord Hectic, and the whole will be settled immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Wait upon Lord Hectic, Sir!—there is no house on earth I would not sooner go to—no place so terrible, except the present—Heavens! I shall run dis∣tracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, don't hesitate.

SP.SPEAKER: Anna.
SP.P: My dear lady, I'm so glad—Mr. Loveless is coming across the meadow, and will be here in a few minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P:
(falling on her knees) O Sir, on my knees let me implore your pity—'tis not pecuniary relief I want—take twice the sum that I am indebted—'tis an unhappy woman, torn with ten thousand agonizing pangs, that kneels for our compassion, and only begs permission to
retire—I would not for the world be seen by Mr. Loveless.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Not seen by Mr. Loveless—some former keeper, I suppose; it will be as well to take advantage of this discovery. (aside)—Rise, Madam, I would not for the world you should be caught—you may depend upon my silence—there's no occasion to declare the whole truth, you know, unless one's sworn in court—so, Ma∣dam, as your chaise is at the door, we can pop into it, and drive to my Lord's together; for we must have your dis∣charge from himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (rising) I see, Sir, you are inexorable.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, Ma'am, very conscientious in the dis∣charge of my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: To go there is dreadful—to stay here is ruin.—Lead on, Sir—I can brave any shock but this.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: (going out) Gad, this distress is very fortu∣nate—I should never have carried my point without it.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (to Anna, who is following) Tarry a while, my Anna—and tell the stranger, when he comes to hear how rudely I have been driven from this last and only shelter—tell him, that Louisa's wrongs, her ceaseless anguish, and her shorten'd life, will one day rise in dreadful evi∣dence against the cruel author of them all. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
A Saloon in LORD HECTIC'S House.
DIV3.P: YES, the distinction is just, and I feel its force—guilty as I have been, dare I revolt against any epithet of reproach which the father of my Julia here bestows upon me?—Yes, I have outrag'd the peace of an innocent family, and call'd Heaven to witness the viola∣tion of its own rites. Can I then oppose myself against the life of a parent, whose wrongs already rise beyond re∣dress? I shudder at the thought.
Oh, my friend, excuse the haste with which I sent to you—indeed your presence is most welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: My dear Loveless, I instantly obey'd your summons—but say, explain to me the cause of this emotion.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (giving a letter) Read that—and you will know.

LETTER.P:
The offer of a pecuniary recompence I treat with the contempt it merits, because I find how deeply I have been injured. While I look'd upon my child as a wanton, who yielded to the solicitation, the disho∣nourable
solicitation, of a pretended lover, I held her cause beneath the dignity of a soldier's arm; an arm worn in the honourable service of his country, never sullied in the defence of infamy and shame—but when I learn, for the first time, she has been betray'd by a pretended solemnization of marriage, and that she has fallen a victim to that fraud, and my unjust displeasure; every remembrance of my un∣happy child now upbraids the tardiness of my arm—old as I am—and sinking beneath the pressure of my woes, I have flown to this spot; and shall only add, that I expect you an hour hence, at the outskirts of the grove.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (taking back the letter) Well—is he not right?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: The warmth of a parent is natural, and ought to be excused. You, however, must not be pro∣vok'd at it—meeting him would be impossible.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Why, so I have thought—but then, my friend, can I submit to epithets, under which no man ought to live?—Should he stigmatize me as a coward, will the world make allowances for my situation, or be∣lieve that he is the only man on earth I would not meet?

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: And would you then so far comply with the false idea which that world calls honour, as to raise your arm against a man already too much injured?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Mistake me not—I have no such intention—I have been the aggressor; and 'tis proper, if such is the reparation he wishes, that I shou'd abide its conse∣quence—yes, I will meet him—but without resistance—I shall offer myself a willing victim to his resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P:
Well, Loveless, if such are your resolu∣tions, let me at least go with you—perhaps it may be in my power to convince Captain Hardy, that, notwith∣standing
the savage practice we see every day enforced, a duel never yet afforded a recompence for a wrong—life may be taken, but satisfaction will not be obtained: and I submit it to every thinking man, who has unfortunately been led into such a situation, whether, the moment re∣venge was complete, peace of mind was not destroyed? I must insist, therefore, on being permitted to attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: No, Belcour, that painful task let me excuse you: in these cases an indifferent man is best; for, though it be the task of a friend, it is the last office he should undertake. On this occasion I mean to ask the kindness of Lord Hectic—his sensibility will not suffer as an ac∣quaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Unkind Loveless! And can you imagine I shall suffer less, because I am not present?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Pray spare me. (as going)—One thing, how∣ever, I wish to mention—Should any thing happen, should this be the last time I embrace my friend, the fa∣ther of my Julia will still find I have not forgotten him. The bulk of my fortune, however, you will be the heir to—if therefore a wish for your Harriet still hangs about your heart, let my last request enforce your own appli∣cation, for her to share it with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: I am overpower'd by your goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: One thing more—I have taken the liberty of leaving a small bequest to the lady in whose cause we have interested ourselves: and, according to my promise, have secured the independency of her son. Should she wonder why a stranger has been thus attentive to her concerns, inform her of my story, and tell her it was the peace-offering of a man who had once injured the purest of female excellence. [Exit hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: BELCOUR.
SP.P: Generous Loveless! Be it mine, in return for thy friendship, to prevent any advantage I might receive from thy misfortune.—Poor Harriet! Loveless would use thee tenderly—but I have treated thee with unkind∣ness. She now suspects me of an unworthy attachment to her once-loved friend Louisa, and bitterly upbraids us both:—let me then haste to undeceive her; and, regardless of worldly considerations, lay my erring heart at her feet, and rely upon the tenderness of her's to pardon and ac∣cept it. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE II.
A cabinet in LORD HECTIC'S house, hung round with pic∣tures of ladies. One frame empty. He surveying them with a pocket-glass, and dusting them with his pocket-hand∣kerchief.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord HECTIC.
SP.P: A man of fashion should patronize the arts; and there∣fore, whenever I succeed with a lady, I always have her picture drawn; by which means I encourage painting, and perpetuate my own atchievements. (Looking at the empty frame) I must have that vacancy though filled up: I ordered the frame, I think, when I first conceived a passion for Louisa;—hem!—t will really fully, if I am not happy in a short time.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P:
What the devil can you mean by poring over a trumpery frame, that you intend to make into a
picture, though upon my shoul the original will never come after the copy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: What the devil art thou talking about? Why thou art drunk—absolutely drunk.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Faith! and I am no such thing, honey!—I am as so—ber as any gentleman ought to be, that is a soldier, d'ye see.—So I tell you now, in sober sadness, you may give up all thoughts of Madam Louisa, for she has fixed her sweet affections upon another person.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Hem! hem! (coughing)—You really have choaked me:—fix'd her affections upon another!—what?—Whom do you mean?—how?—when?—where?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Where!—why about two yards and a half from you. If you look straight to me, you can't miss seeing him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Why, Captain Swagger! thou hast sure∣ly forgotten whom thou art speaking of—and what thou art saying.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O, to be sure! and I am to blame if she has fixed her affections, as I said, upon a sober gentleman∣like person called Captain Swagger!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Upon thee—thou animal!

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Yes, by St. Patrick! for when I went there, just to speak a few words in your favour—Oh, says she, Captain (with a smile that quite bother'd me) how can you waste your time thus, when perhaps I may have disposed of my heart to another?—Another!—Upon my shoul, and I take these things as quick as any man in all England.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Drunk—absolutely drunk.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter JANUS, and whispers LORD HECTIC.
DIV3.P: Louisa coming to wait upon me!—hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Yes, only a little timorous, as she is afraid of some former keeper, who has discovered her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: You overcome me with gratitude, my dear friend;—twist yourself out immediately, and drive that cousin of mine before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Janus.
SP.P: Come, Captain, as you seem very clear∣headed, suppose you retire to study a little in my Lord's library. (shoving him)

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: Well, well, I will go and study—but I am the most complaisant crater in the world, to leave a room when a woman is in love with me. (Janus pushes him out)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Hem! hem!—Upon my word this un∣expected visit has a little deranged my nerves.—Where the devil is my tincture of sage, to give me confidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My Lord, you will doubtless be surprized at so extraordinary a visit, from one whose misfortunes alone are all she has to plead—misfortunes which your Lord∣ship has (I hope unintentionally) very considerably in∣creased. Depressed with cureless griefs, and nearly yield∣ing to a sad despondency, I had found one kind asylum, I had secured one tender friend:—friendship and privacy, the only consolations I could feel, your Lordship's impor∣tunities have deprived me of—but I cannot, will not, sup∣pose your heart has consented to such injurious conduct—and therefore have determined to make this personal appeal to your compassion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Really, upon my word, you did very right.—She begins in heroics, I see—a certain sign she'll come down. (aside)—Pray, Madam, be seated.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I beg, my Lord, we may wave attentions—I have already too much reason to complain of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: My dear Madam, I hope not—I shou'd be the most mortified creature breathing.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: A person who informs me he acts for your lordship, has subjected me to great inconvenience; it is in your power to oblige me most essentially—There is a gentleman—I hope I may speak with confidence—nobody can break in upon your lordship?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: O, not a soul—however I'll take the pre∣caution of locking the door.—Yes, I see the frame will soon be filled up. (returns from the door)—You may de∣pend upon it, Madam, we are safe. I am exceedingly nice about a lady's reputation, and never mention a thing afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Let me then hope you will put a stop to the injustice which your lawyer has been guilty of in your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: O dear, madam, never mind—you know what an attorney is, and won't be surprized at any thing he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Indeed I imagined his conduct wou'd never meet with your concurrence; and some reasons, peculiar to my fortune and situation, making my immediate retreat necessary, I was induced to take this step—perhaps too forward—that I might not suffer the delays of imperti∣nence, or the insults of mean power.—From your lord∣ship, notwithstanding former mistakes, I trusted a help∣less female would find security and redress.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Without doubt, Madam—I assure you you are quite safe—pray do not rise—nothing can be more snug. (knock)—(aside) What the devil is that? (start∣ing up.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa
SP.P:
(rising) I beg, my Lord, you will use no ce∣remony—I would not be seen for the world—I can retire
the other way.—Here is the full amount of my debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Pray, Madam—I request, I entreat (knock∣ing)—Zounds! was ever nobleman so interrupted?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (without) My Lord, I ask your pardon—

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O Heavens Loveless's voice (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Don't be alarmed—it is only a gentle∣man, whom you don't know—a visitor of mine—a queer formal sort of fellow—Do me the favour only to step into that room, I'll turn him out again in an instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (without) Pray, my Lord, let me speak to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: (calling to him) In a minute, Loveless—in a minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: What shall I do?—Should he discover me in this situation, how dreadful will it be! (going towards the apartment.) Let me entreat you not to mention my name, or even hint that a lady is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Certainly not, Ma'am—I'm the most careful man about a lady's reputation. (shews her into the other room)—Damn this fellow's interruption; what can he want, an impertinent rascal? (opens the door.)—My dear friend, I am very glad to see you—but how the devil could you interrupt a man at such a crisis?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: I beg your pardon, my Lord, if I have in∣truded—but the case would not admit of delay—I must request your attention for a moment to a very disagree∣able business.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: I am orry for it—but I can attend to nothing now, but very pleasant business.—Betwixt our∣selves, there is a lady in the other room—but she desired me not to speak of it—You understand me—when a lady's in the case—hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P:
I acknowledge the privilege—but in one
word then, I am unfortunately involved in an affair of honour, and must request your assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Zounds! how can I think of an affair of honour, when I have got a fine woman waiting for me—or what wou'd she think of me, if I did?—why, I tell you its the handsome widow that I was mentioning, that you and Belcour were moralizing about—had not you unfortunately broke in upon me—the day had been mine already.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Really!—Louisa a wanton!—then, indeed, I've been deceived—

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: That may be—but I am never deceiv'd about the women. When I pursue, I always succeed.—Look at these pictures, they are my trophies—that frame will soon be filled up—Louisa's ready to sit; pop her in in a week:—but I don't speak out of vanity.—So now, my dear friend, damn your duel, and turn yourself out as quick as you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Well, my Lord, I will wait your leisure.—Success is the parent of levity, and therefore I excuse yours.—Unthinking Louisa! thus to sacrifice thyself.—Had the angel whom I deceiv'd but resembled thee, how short would have been my regret! (aside) [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: (going to the door of the inner room) Well, all is safe, my dame of Ephesus—that damn'd fellow is gone. (Louisa comes out) Come, don't be frighten'd, my angel—Lord Hectic is protection itself—hem! hem!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Thank Heaven, it is past—and now, since I can depart with security, let me not again run the risk of subjecting myself and your lordship to the impertinence of suspicion.—I wish you a good day. (going)

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
Pray, Ma'am—I beg Ma'am, you will compose yourself;—I could not think of letting you go so—so fright'ned and flurried as you must have been!—tha
cursed fellow, who has no more nerves than a porter—pray sit down and compose yourself, my love.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: I hope, my Lord, you will give no reason to alter the favourable opinion I had begun to form of your humanity; or to repent the resolution, which led me, in a moment of distress, to fly to your Lordship for protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Come, come, my dear Madam, you excel in heroics, and I love them at proper times; but ladies don't visit gentlemen for nothing.—I am a man of fashion and pleasure!—hem! hem!—and I am ambitious to see you at the head of both:—so come, throw aside this—this unnecessary reserve. (Seizing her hand.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Free my hand, my Lord, this instant—or, by all that's sacred, I'll alarm the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Oh dear! my family are alarmed at no∣thing;—come, Ma'am, taste and happiness are in your reach—a neat house in London—four ponies for Hyde∣park—consent, my angel—nay, you must—you shall—
SP.STAGE: [Attempts to be rude, she screams, and Loveless rushes in; on which she faints, and falls.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: Why what the devil brings you back again, Loveless? don't you see▪ the lady faints at the sight of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (goes up to her) Gracious Powers! what miracle is this? can it be possible?—can it be my Julia whom I see (raises her) in such a situation?—Speak! breathe! look! and relieve my agonizing doubts!—My Lord, my Lord, what excuse can you make?—Revive, my adored Julia, and explain this mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
Egad, I have got into the wrong box; and I may as well get out of it as soon as I can. (aside)—Well, Mr. Loveless, if this is really your Julia, as you call her—I never trespass upon any gentleman's property,
and therefore—hem!—I have the honour to wish you a good morning. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (striving to raise her) And yet, to be found with a man of Lord Hectic's character!—My love! my wife! my long-lost Julia!—assure yourself you are in the hands of a man who would die to protect you—in the arms of your Loveless.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (starting) Loveless! Oh! (breaking from him) too well I recollect that name! the fatal, fatal cause of all my sufferings!

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Let me thank Heaven that thou art still alive!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yes, I am alive—inhuman Loveless! alive to every wretchedness thy cruelty has heap'd upon me!—betray'd by thee, in youth's unguarded morn—I have liv'd the scorn of my sex, and the sport of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: I have indeed been guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My first, my tenderest love being basely sacri∣ficed to sordid interest and mean ambition, I have been forced, with the keen pangs of wounded sensibility, to bear the weight of undeserv'd reproach.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Oh! spare me, Julia—look on me as I am, an alter'd man—peace has been a stranger to my bosom, and remorse and sorrow my constant companions, since we parted.—My heart is open but to the charms of virtue, and trembles only at the uncertainty of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: My child, thy much-wrong'd child, too cruel man! who now must blush to own his birth, but for thy treachery would have smil'd upon our mutual happiness, and rais'd his infant voice to bless his father.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P:
Yes, Madam, I feel, severely feel the justice of your complaints! yet I could urge some heart-felt ighs, I could bring witnesses of some repentant tears; tears which hourly trickled down my cheek, when I hought the injured excellence, whose memory made
them flow, had long been lost to every earthly recom∣pence.—I lov'd my boy, before I knew he was so. I felt for his mother's wrongs, when I could little suppose myself the sad aggressor.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Loveless, 'tis now too late to parley—you may awaken remembrance; you can never restore my peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: I am distracted with a thousand thoughts—I destroy'd thy innocence; yet dread to find it wanting—tell me then, in pity tell me, how it comes, that, after having evaded all my fond enquiries, I now find you in Lord Hectic's own apartments, and studiously concealed at my approach?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yes, Sir; usurp the right which my credulity has given you, to upbraid me with misfortunes which, even at this late period, you have been the cause of.—But for Loveless, Lord Hectic had been unknown.—How∣ever, conscious of no ill, I disclaim justification—and Mr. Loveless is, perhaps, the only man on earth to whom I am not solicitous of appearing innocent; because, himself having lost all that was valuable in my eyes, his approbation now can give me no concern.—I beg, Sir, that I may be permitted to depart. (going.)

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Stay, I conjure you, stay:—wrong'd as you have been by my crimes, and now, perhaps, wrong'd by my suspicions, deign to forgive a man, whose strong affection has been his guilt:—by every tie of na∣ture I entreat you, hear me; by our son's welfare, by your hopes of happiness hereafter, inform me why you have eluded all my anxious searches, and found me only in these hated rooms?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P:
There was a time when I should not have been suspected on such grounds:—from the tenor of my conduct, even from my enemies, you will learn the
injustice you are now guilty of.—But enough of words have pass'd between us.—In the retirement which I shall seek, and which I hope you will not attempt to invade, no reproaches of mine shall wound your ear again. Oh, Loveless!—protect your son—protect my only child—rear him in the paths of honour—teach him to avoid his father's errors—to lament his mother's fate!—So shall my ebbing life know something of content; and my boy's rising virtues shade his parent's faults, when you can wound, and I can weep no more. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Yes, I will obey thy injunctions, and not break in upon thy grief.—Every prospect of a reconcilia∣tion is now at an end—what then remains for me?—a father's rage—a father's vengeful sword. [Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE III.
Another Apartment in LORD HECTIC'S House, with folding∣doors in the back Scene.
DIV3.STAGE: LADY BETTY WORMWOOD and MISS PENELOPE ZODIAC, meeting in a great hurry.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Fine doings here, indeed, Lady Betty!—so that abominable Louisa has got into the house, at last!—Mercy on us!—What will become of me, as an un∣married lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: True, Miss Penelope, you are in the right to be apprehensive in time;—I had just heard of it from my maid.—If it was not proper that some people should think of title and fortune in a great family, I should actually give my brother up.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P:
Paugh! The very house is tainted with the creature.—But I have lock'd up my room, lest she
should run away with some of my poetry.—Those sort of animals are glad to lay their hands upon any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: As to your poetry, I believe you need not have been afraid; for such wretches only steal things of value—but, at all events, the hussey must be disposed of;—I shall consult my attorney immediately—in the mean time, do me the favour to look thro' the key-hole of my Lord's library, and observe what's going for∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I look thro' the key-hole!—Heaven knows what I may be witness to!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Nay, my dear friend, throw aside these scruples—nobody will suspect you, as you are a learned lady, you know, and not supposed to think about such things. But my brother wou'd never forgive me, tho' I do it entirely out of kindness to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: If you really thought there wou'd be no harm in it, why I wou'd give a peep—merely tho' to oblige you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: You are too good.—How glad she is to listen!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Pray take care that nobody comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: I am sorry, Lady Betty, to be trou∣blesome—but I have been informed, that a lawyer, on your account, has given great uneasiness to a lady for whom I have a most profound regard. (seeing Miss Penelope)—Miss Penelope, I ask ten thousand par∣dons, I did not intend to mention my attachments any more in your company, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: I beg, Colonel, you will not address your improper discourse to me; as I'm an unmarried woman, and cannot possibly hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P:
Sir, if my lawyer has been guilty of any
severity against the person in question, he did not per∣haps know that Colonel Quorum was not very inqui∣sitive about the character of the ladies for whom he profess'd a regard.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: The devil, Madam!—I ask pardon for swearing; but, zounds! her character has been misre∣presented—and your Ladyship's usage has driven her from the friends that value her, to seek shelter, perhaps, in solitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Yes:—at least, if she's not alone, I dare say she has not above one person with her.—Ha! Lady Betty!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: One person!—who knows, but she is now wandering thro' woods and wilds, friendless and unattended, and her tender frame exposed to every hardship?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I won't say what her tender frame may be exposed to; but I am sure, if she is wandering thro' woods and wilds, she has met with them in my Lord's library.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Upon my honour, I can't comprehend what your Ladyship means; but sure, after the impor∣tunities she had already withstood from your brother—she deserved every respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: But are you so certain she has withstood those importunities?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Confusion, Madam!—permit me to in∣form you, that she has withstood the most honourable temptations; I only wish that she might appear, to con∣found all the ill-natur'd surmises of her enemies.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Well, Colonel, if you are so desirous of her appearing, I believe you have nothing in the world to do, but to open that door.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P:
Zounds!—'tis impossible!—and if I thought so, I'd have the Posse Comitatus, and bring her
to light immediately—I have already dispatch'd my clerk, with a search-warrant and two field-pieces, to Sir Gregory Glovetop's; and by Heavens I'll leave no corner unsearch'd!—nay, I'll break the door open my∣self;—am I not a justice of peace? and don't I know the law upon these matters?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: I hope he will do it.—How I shall en∣joy the creature's confusion!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: I say, in the King's name, open the door, that justice may enter, and guilt be put to flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: (throwing open the Glass Doors, and coming out half asleep.) The devil burn me, but what is all this bother here?—Can't a gentleman study, without being interrupted?

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: There, Madam, I told you there was nothing pure in that apartment; and the Captain is a proof of it!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Pure, Colonel! I never thought there was—but I shall be look'd on as a fallen star myself, if I stay any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: Some people will not believe their own eyes, nor other people their own ears—but, thank Hea∣ven! my senses are perfect; and I shall take my leave of people who have lost theirs. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Aye, to be sure—the ignorance of some folks is astonishing. [Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: (speaking after them) Yes, ladies, and the malice of others.—But, by Heaven, if Lord Hectic only dares to say that he has seen an apartment belonging to Louisa; or if you, Sir,—but I know the state of your feelings already, and how little they resemble those of your countrymen.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P:
Upon my shoul, if any body knows any
thing of my feeling, its more than I do—and by my faith they may keep their knowledge to themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Shew me the way to his Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: I shew you the way!

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Blood and thunder!—do you dis∣pute?

SP.SPEAKER: Swagger.
SP.P: O, by no means—I'd sooner shew you to the devil.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
The Grove.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter CAPTAIN HARDY and LOVELESS, meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: At length then we are met—few words are best, when language wou'd but ill describe the weight of guilt, or paint the feelings of an injur'd parent. Come, Sir, draw and defend yourself—justice upbraids my slow revenge, and my poor child's departed spirit calls on her father to vindicate her memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Hold, Captain Hardy! hold!—nor force me to raise my arm against a man for whom my heart already bleeds.—Your daughter lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: Paltry artifice!—Her death, alas! is not less certain to me than her dishonour—therefore drop this un∣necessary parley, and what you cannot justify, dare at least defend.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: For Heaven's sake, Sir, urge me no farther—at least satisfy yourself of the reality of your daughter's existence. On my honour she lives—lives to console your afflictions; would I could add, to join her entreaties to mine, to bury your resentment!

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P:
Impossible—'tis nothing but a mean subter∣fuge.—Draw, I insist upon it, this moment—for, sunk and
despicable as thou art, not even the contempt thou me∣ritest shall save thee. (they fight.)

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LOUISA, HARRIOT, BELCOUR, and the CHILD.
(She throws herself on her knees between them.)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Hold, hold, your vengeful arms—see at your feet the unhappy cause of all your animosity.—O, my father—let me not lose that title in the very moment I re∣cover it—make not an orphan of my infant child.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: My daughter alive!—imploring those who most have wrong'd her!

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Yes, my honour'd sire—your long-lost daugh∣ter sues for your compassion. Oh, my father—will you forgive the errors of my youth—pardon the sorrows I have brought upon you—and, in mercy to your daughter, sheath your sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: Rise, my child.—You are not the offender—but you know not what you ask—your sufferings now call louder for redress. (offering again to fight, prevented by BELCOUR) Well, Sir, we shall yet meet—(putting up his sword) a father's vengeance cannot be eluded.—My child's misfortunes do not want forgiveness—but her un∣merited disgrace shall be atoned.

SP.SPEAKER: Belcour.
SP.P: Pray let me interpose—as friend to all, as friend to nature and humanity.—“My Harriet too, the companion of your daughter's lonely hours, shall join her solicitations to mine—we have both been faithful witnesses of Loveless's contrition and his pangs, when they must have been sincere”—had he fallen by your arm, the last distribution of his effects would have done credit to his honour, to his affection, to his repentance. We have painted them all to your daughter, and nature pleads strongly on his side—let your consent then autho∣rize her forgiveness.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: Your forgiveness!—and is it so, my child?

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: O frown not on me, Sir—doom'd to long an∣guish and unceasing tears, merited perhaps by my own unguardedness, never again shall your Julia indulge her feelings, but when your approbation first sanctifies her choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: (taking her hand) Spoke like the daughter my heart pants again to be allied with—look then with re∣sentment on a man who left thee to sorrow and to shame—Come, my poor suffering child, and shew that insolent, who dar'd reject thee in his proudest hour, that thou can'st rise above the day of thy humiliation. (offers to lead her out)

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (in great agitation) Let my dear boy then, our pledge of former tenderness, remain with me; and make me some amends for the loss of his unrelenting grandsire, and too cruel mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: (looking at her father, then at Loveless) O, Sir, forgive me, if nature claims one tear, that yet rends my heart!—and tell me, oh, my father—tell me how—how a parent ought to act—

SP.SPEAKER: Harriet.
SP.P: (advancing with the child) Look, Sir, on this blameless infant, whose childhood has been mark'd with calamity,—whose growing years can open only to his father's anguish, and his mother's grief—think that your forgiveness can obliterate them all—and then deny it to him, if you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P:
I am conquer'd—I am not proof against that innocent (clasping the child)—come, my poor mourner, to my aged arms, while yet I've life to succour you.—Oh! Loveless, forgive my hasty rage, your father now requests it.—Approach, my child (to his daughter)—lend me your hand—thus I bestow it; and thus with nature' tenderest
tie I bind it fast (placing the child between them)—bless the sweet instrument of my forgiveness, and cherish him as the source of your unfading love.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: (embracing her) My Julia—my recover'd wife!—tears choak my utterance.

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Loveless, to find thee thus—a convert to that charming tenderness, which, founded in honour alone, brings every permanent and soft delight—to see my honour'd father smiling on his new-born joys—to clasp my much-loy'd friend (to Harriet) and know her happy as her heart can desire, I will freely and gratefully ac∣knowledge fate has not left me now one wish to form.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Separate the parties immediately, I say, before they do any mischief.—While I am a magistrate no duel shall be tolerated.—Louisa here!—I hope, Madam, you were not going to engage.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: Yes, Colonel, and for life, I flatter myself—Louisa is my Julia—is my wife▪

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Your wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: I do not wonder at your astonishment; but you soon shall be appriz'd of every thing—you, Sir, are entitled to our confidence as well as friendship, for I know no one to whom this lady has been more oblig'd.—Your good opinion, I am inform'd, remained unaltered by her distress.

SP.SPEAKER: Col. Quorum.
SP.P: Ah! I am afraid there was a little of self∣love in that, after all.—But if you, Madam, can forget my passion, I will endeavour to forget it too.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P:
Well, Mr. Loveless, I see you are alive—
and therefore I hope I am not too late for a second—The ladies here!—Oh—hem!—then Mars must yield to Ve∣nus.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter LADY BETTY and MISS PENELOPE.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Betty.
SP.P: My brother's voice!—then I am sure the odious creature is not far off, and I dare say encircled with the men too.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Penelope.
SP.P: Yes, always wand'ring into another person's sphere.

SP.SPEAKER: Hardy.
SP.P: Pray who are these good-natured ladies, that are pleas'd to make such kind observations on my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Hectic.
SP.P: One of these ladies I have the honour to call sister, and the other is a virgin aunt of this gen∣tleman—but I really can't answer for either of their good∣nature. However, Madam, as you are now in the possession of my friend Loveless—who I told you was a good sort of man, only a little formal, I will give up my pretensions, and fairly confess you are in better hands.—Ah! that frame must remain vacant, I see. (aside)

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P: My Lord, I thank you, and if you will per∣mit me to offer you and these ladies one word of advice, it would be, that, while you desisted from attempting to give cause for scandal, they should relinquish exercising it without any cause at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: And so, child, you have broke through all etiquette, and actually been forward enough to step out of my house with a gentleman, perhaps of no precedence at all, and without a pedigree!—I should have been exceed∣ingly angry, but I never am vex'd before good company.

SP.SPEAKER: Loveless.
SP.P:
Sir Gregory, Mr. Belcour is my friend, and his rank and fortune will entitle him, I believe, in your
opinion, to pardon at court—and now let me introduce you to a lady, formerly an acquaintance of your's.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Gregory.
SP.P: What, Louisa!—very true—one of the hous∣hold, I protest—ah I said, if she had a proper idea of conse∣quence, and got quit of sorrow and affection, and all that, she would do very well yet—and my little fellow here shall be a page after all—and I'll keep my promise, and teach him the true court-step myself—ha! ha!—Soft and majestic, with a little grace upon the toe. (moving about)

SP.SPEAKER: Louisa.
SP.P: Ah, Sir Gregory—you have been somewhat wanting in politeness to me, but I forgive you.—Restored to objects dearer to me than life, I can have no right to complain.

LG.L: Surrounded thus with all that life can give
To warm my heart, and make me wish to live▪
Charm'd with the generous friends, who, circled here,
Feel for each pang, and give me tear for tear,
Be it mine to thank them for their tender cares,
And let my future hours be wholly theirs▪
FIVE dismal acts consum'd in lamentation,
Our Author marries me for Reparation!
—Well—tho' we women are, as grey-beards say,
In duty bound to love and to obey;
And, tho' beset with cares of brats and strife,
Repent is still the lot of married life;
With less dismay I meet the awful sentence,
Since wedlock puts an end to my repentance.
From this bright hour shall gayer scenes arise,
Such as may charm a female patriot's eyes,
Whose great ambition sars to nobler plans
Than goat's-beard tippets, or than Marlbrou fans:
Whose taste the rage for Opera can defy,
And bear to live—tho' Pacchierotti die:
With strange ill-bred indifference can view
VESTRIS on one leg, or—the Dogs on two.
But as we women are forbid to roam,
And though we will speak last—must speak at home—
To spouse I delegate my vocal powers,
He knows my voice—and hears it at all hours—
Thus, t in hand, and poiz'd upon one leg,
He'll start with—"Mr. Speaker!—Sir—I beg
"One word."—"Oh, hear him! hear him!—I defy
"The honourable member in my eye."
Then o'er the Indian plains his forces rally,
Rave about TIPPOO SAIB and HEYDER ALLY;
While I, the member's wife, shall bear a shawl
Given by some ponderous prnce of Leadenhall:
Or, up all night, with fresh impatience wait,
To read next noon the Chronicled debate;
Where, in good style, and better words convey'd,
Spouse wonders at the speeches he has made,
And, with the borrow'd grace enamour'd grown,
Stares o'er the tropes and figures—not his own.
Such is the potent spell that all bewitches—
"For who would fardels bear,"—that could make speeches?
"Who brook th' oppressor's wrong—the proud man's eye,"
When he might rise again—with, I reply?
"Or who would groan beneath life's weary prate,"
Who quietly might sleep thro' a debate?
But—there are charms from oratory flow,
Which those who only hear, can never know.
Yet, lest I press too long the speaker's art,
Pass me your vot of thanks—and I depart.
